story:
Help Us Help Syrian Refugees in Southern France (la traduction Française est ci-dessous)

The wave of Syrian refugees currently washing over Europe is real. Wendela and I are experiencing it personally in our new home in France. 

We have, in the past few weeks been part of the founding of a network of concerned French and foreign individuals who are devoted to doing what we can to ease the situation of refugees arriving here after months (and for some, years) of a very tough existence. 

The group we are currently helping includes about 40 people, including 14 children,  They were forced from their homes in Syria and made their way here via Egypt, Libya, Algeria, Morocco and Spain. Their resources are exhausted and so are they. They are squatting now in condemned apartments in a town nearby.

Our group, Languedoc Solidarity with Refugees/Solidarité avec les réfugiés, is helping them to survive while their applications for political asylum are considered by the French government. Once their applications are accepted (usually a matter of weeks) they will be eligible for some minimal assistance from the government but, in the meantime, they are on their own. Organizing ourselves very quickly, we have been able to provide them with basic food supplies, warm clothes and bedding, emergency medical care and logistical support in dealing with the local bureaucracy.

We have raised approximately $6,000 (Euros 5,400) in the past five weeks in a combination of material and financial contributions. The number of refugees assisted goes up and down as some successfully transition into the French system and new ones arrive. The truth is that we don't know what it will all look like next week but, over the next several months we are expecting the need to increase overall. The funds raised by this appeal will help us maintain the current level of support for another six weeks.

I (Gary) am the treasurer of this group.  All contributions to this campaign will come to me directly and I will personally turn them over to the group as expenses are incurred. I can personally assure all donors that every penny and centime will be used to help these people who need it so badly.  Those of you who know us, know how seriously we take this responsibility and how committed we are to helping these families. And, in our interaction with them over the past weeks, we are reminded again that they are not statistics, a political issue, or a faceless mass.  They are fathers and mothers, husbands and wives, children and babies with problems that the rest of us can hardly conceive of. They are not coming here out of choice but out of fear and concern for their children.They would much prefer to be living their lives in peace in their own homes.

Please dig in a little bit to help us help them. 


Aidez-Nous à Aider les Réfugiés Syriens dans le Sud de la France.

La vague de réfugiés Syriens qui déferle actuellement sur toute l'Europe est bien réelle. Wendela et moi-même en sommes personnellement  témoins dans notre nouveau pays d'accueil qu'est la France.

Nous avons, au cours de ces dernières semaines, pris part à la création d'un réseau de Français et d'étrangers extrêmement motivés qui se consacrent à faire tout leur possible pour améliorer la situation des réfugiés arrivés ici après des mois (des années pour certains), d'une existence extrêmement rude. 

Le groupe de réfugiés que nous aidons aujourd'hui comprend environ 40 personnes, dont 14 enfants. Ils ont été contraints de quitter leur maison en  Syrie et sont parvenus jusqu'ici après avoir traversé l'Egypte, la Libye, l'Algérie, le Maroc et l'Espagne. Leurs ressources sont épuisées, tout comme ils le sont eux-mêmes. Ils squattent actuellement des appartements déclarés inhabitables dans une ville des environs.

Notre groupe, Languedoc Solidarity with Refugees/Solidarité avec les réfugiés, les aide à survivre pendant que leur demande de droit d'asile est examinée par les autorités françaises. Une fois celle-ci acceptée (cela prend généralement quelques semaines), ils deviennent éligibles à certaines prestations sociales minimums mais, durant cette attente, sont seulement livrés à eux-mêmes. Après nous être rapidement organisés, nous avons réussi à leur fournir des vivres de base, des vêtements chauds et des couchages, l'accès à des soins médicaux d'urgence et une aide logistique afin de faire face à la bureaucratie locale. 

Je m'appelle Gary et je suis le Trésorier de ce groupe. Toutes les contributions reçues au cours de cette campagne passeront entre mes mains, et je les reverserai personnellement au groupe en fonction des besoins. Je me porte personnellement garant auprès des donateurs que chaque centime versé le sera exclusivement au profit de ces gens qui en ont tant besoin. Ceux parmi vous qui nous connaissent déjà savent avec quel sérieux nous engageons notre responsabilité et à quel point nous nous sommes investis pour aider ces gens. Dans notre relation avec eux au cours des dernières semaines, nous avons pu constater qu'ils ne sont ni des statistiques, ni un problème politique ni une foule sans visage. Ils sont des pères et des mères, des maris et des femmes, des enfants et des bébés avec des difficultés que nous ne pouvons même pas concevoir. Ces hommes et ces femmes ne sont pas venus ici par choix mais par peur et par inquiétude pour leurs enfants. Ils préfèreraient, et de loin, continuer à vivre paisiblement leur vie chez eux. 

Nous vous demandons de faire un petit effort pour nous aider à les aider.

story:
Herkese Merhaba!

Biz Merve ve Seben. İki ilkokul arkadaşıyız. İkimiz de sosyal bilimler alanında eğitim aldık ve bu alanlarda eğitim üzerine uzmanlaştık. 3 yıldan fazla bir süredir eğitim üzerine tecrübelerimiz var.

Türkiye’de eğitimin en büyük toplumsal sorunlardan biri olduğunu bildiğimiz için, dünyada uygulanan alternatif eğitim sistemlerini inceledik. Bunları Türk kültürel yapısına en uygun biçimde nasıl aşılarız diye epey kafa yorduk. Sonunda İtalya kökenli bir eğitim sistemi olan Reggio Emilia’nın ülkemizde uygulanabilecek en güzel sistem olduğuna karar verdik. Hedefimiz bu eğitim felsefesini önce kendi açacağımız danışmanlık şirketiyle, istekli anaokulları ve ilkokullara ulaştırabilmek. Sonrasında ise, bu felsefeyi Türk kültürel değerleriyle harmanlayıp, kendi eğitim sistemimizi değiştirmek için bir AR-GE merkezi kurabilmek. Bu ülkenin çocuklarının yaratıcı düşünebilen, üreten, sorgulayan, araştıran, kendi kendine öğrenebilen, temel değerlerine saygılı ve sahip çıkabilen, evrensel ahlak değerlerine de sahip, sosyal-duygusal alanlarda gelişmiş, iyi yurttaş ve iyi insan olarak yetişebilecekleri okullar kurulmasına katkı sağlamak nihai amacımız.

Tüm bunların yanında temel amaçlarımızdan bir diğeri ise, hangi engel grubuna dahil olursa olsun, tüm özel gereksinimli bireylere eşit şartlarda eğitim hakkı verebilmek ve bu doğrultuda yeni yöntemler geliştirebilmek. Tüm engelli çocukların hak temelli sosyal yaklaşım modeli içinde eğim hayatlarını sürdürmelerini sağlayabilmektir.

Tüm bunları gerçekleştirebilmemiz için, bu yaz katılmamız gereken iki eğitim var. Bunlardan biri, İtalya'da Reggio Emilia felsefesi üzerine bir yaz okulu eğitimi. Diğeri de ABD’de kapsamlı bir akademik eğitim İngilizcesi eğitimi. ABD’de dil eğitimi almak istememizin yine Reggio Emilia ile bir bağlantısı var aslında, New York’ta Reggio Emilia felsefesiyle eğitim veren kurumlar var. Amacımız dil eğitimi aldığımız sırada oradaki Reggio Emilia felsefesini uygulayan okulları da gezip, felsefeyle ilgili daha çok bilgi ve tecrübe paylaşımında bulunmak.

 

Şimdi sizlere kendimizi tanıtmak istiyoruz.

Ben Seben Dayı 28 yaşındayım. Yüzde 52 oranında Serebral Palsiliyim (Serebral Palsi, doğum anındaki çeşitli komplikasyonlar sonucu beyinde gerçekleşen nörolojik bir durum. Kısa tanımıyla bir tür beyin felci. Vücudun kas kontrolünü kısıtlayan bir hastalık).

Güzel bir çocukluk döneminden sonra, Yeditepe Üniversitesi Gazetecilik Bölümünden mezun oldum. Bu bölümü birincilikle bitirdikten sonra aldığım başarı bursuyla İngilizce Antropoloji bölümünde yüksek lisans yaparak okul hayatıma devam ettim. Gazetecilikte de Antropolojide de eğitimle ilgili çalışmalar yürüttüm. Radikal gazetesi eğitim departmanında Umay Aktaş ile birlikte bir dönem staj yapma şansı buldum. Sonrasında okulun yayın organlarında eğitim ve kültür-sanat alanlarında pek çok haber yaptım. Antropoloji bölümünde yüksek lisans eğitimime başladığım sene, Merve’nin sayesinde alternatif eğitim ve Reggio Emilia yaklaşımıyla tanışmış oldum. Hem Merve’yle birlikte çalıştığımız kurum hem de başka kurumlar olmak üzere iki sene Reggio Emillia felsefesi üzerine çalıştım. Çalıştığım kurumlarda aynı zamanda “çocuk ve engelilik algısı” üzerine farkındalık çalışmaları yürüttüm.

Yüksek lisans derslerimin bitmesiyle tez aşamasına geçtiğim için iş yaşamına ara verdim. Tez için seçtiğim konu, Türkiye’de alternatif eğitim uygulayan okul kültürleri üzerineydi. Bunun için Başka Bir Okul Mümkün Derneği içinde kurulan ilk okul olan “Mutlu Keçi İlkokulu”nda altı aylık bir alan araştırması yaptım. Tezimi Haziran ayında teslim edeceğim.

Katkılarınız sayesinde bu yaz katılacağım eğitimler sonrasında, ülkeye dönüp Merve’yle birlikte eğitim üzerine çalışmalar yapmaya devam etmek, şimdilik tek hayalim..

 

Ben Merve Özkaya, 28 yaşındayım. Marmara Üniversitesi’nde İngilizce Sosyoloji okudum. Üniversitede eğitim sistemine alternatif arayışlarım sırasında Reggio Emilia Yaklaşımı ile tanıştım ve felsefesini araştırmaya başladım. Reggio Emilia ilhamlı özel bir anaokulunda Reggio Emilia Öğretmeni olarak çalıştım. Çocuklarını sisteme kurban etmek istemeyen annelerle tanıştım, onlara Reggio Emilia’yı anlattığım seminerler verdim, çocukları için Reggio Emilia danışmanlığı yaptım, Reggio Emilia ilhamlı atölyeler yaptık. Reggio Emilia’yı kendi kültürümüze uyarlayabilmek için, nasıl bir kültürden çıktığını gözlemlemek üzere kasım 2014 ve mayıs 2016'da (Reggionarra festivali için) Reggio Emilia kasabasına gittim. "Çocuğun 100 Dili Anaokulu"nda kurulumundan itibaren 1,5 yıl eğitim koordinatörlüğü yaptım. İlkokul arkadaşım Seben'le Öncü Eğitimciler Derneği bünyesinde yetişkinler ve çocuklar için Reggio Emilia ilhamlı eğitim ve atölyeler düzenledik. Beraber eğitim ve danışmanlık üzerine projeler yazıp geliştirmekteyiz. Bize inanıp projelerimizi hayata geçirmek üzere bizi destekleyen herkese teşekkür ederim.

 

Aşağıda bize verdiğiniz desteklerin kalem kalem nereye gideceğini görebilirsiniz.

***”Seben acil durum”*** olarak belirttiğimiz kalem, Seben’in özel gereksinimli bir birey olmasından dolayı başımıza gelebilecek olağan durumlar (yürüyemediği noktada taksiye binebilmek, olası bir sağlık probleminde hastaneye gidebilmek vb.) düşünülerek bütçemize konulmuştur.

Bu yazıyı okuyup, videomuzu izleyip bizimle hayallerimizi paylaştığınız için sizlere teşekkür ederiz.

 

                                                                                                     Seben & Merve

 

İtalya Reggio Emilia Eğitimi (16-26 Haziran 10 gün) giderler:
Eğitim masrafı: 2x2.000= 4.000euro
Konaklama: 550 euro
Uçak Bileti: 2x200euro= 400 euro
Vizeler: 2x60=120 euro
Diğer giderler+harçlık+seben acil durum: 930 euro
Toplam: 6.000 euro -- 6600 dolar

Bize inanıp projelerimizi hayata geçirmek üzere bizi destekleyen herkese teşekkür ederim. Aşağıda bize verdiğiniz desteklerin kalem kalem nereye gideceğini görebilirsiniz.***”Seben acil durum”*** olarak belirttiğimiz kalem, Seben’in özel gereksinimli bir birey olmasından dolayı başımıza gelebilecek olağan durumlar (yürüyemediği noktada taksiye binebilmek, olası bir sağlık probleminde hastaneye gidebilmek vb.) düşünülerek bütçemize konulmuştur.Bu yazıyı okuyup, videomuzu izleyip bizimle hayallerimizi paylaştığınız için sizlere teşekkür ederiz.                                                                                                      Seben & Merve İtalya Reggio Emilia Eğitimi (16-26 Haziran 10 gün) giderler:Eğitim masrafı: 2x2.000= 4.000euroKonaklama: 550 euroUçak Bileti: 2x200euro= 400 euroVizeler: 2x60=120 euroDiğer giderler+harçlık+seben acil durum: 930 euroToplam: 6.000 euro -- 6600 dolar

story:
What is Modern High School?

  Modern high school is a government aided institution established in 1958 in Hyderabad,India.It was started to encourage education for the underprivileged children from  the nearby surrounding urban slums of old Hyderabad.

Modern High School was started by Janab Khader Ali Khan , a social worker in 1958 with a strength of 200 students.over the years the strength increased and reached about 1400 in 1971 with a teaching staff of about 40.

But due to the lack of funds over the years,the student strength has been decreasing and reached about 350 in 2015.


What Modern High School Needs

·  Education  here is still limited to the conventional method of blackboard and books.This project is required to raise funds to help the school build better classrooms,a science laboratory,a library and such.Doing so is expected to help the students gain knowledge from a practical perspective and help improve the academic standards of the school and also attract more students to take admission.

The present school funds are insufficient to support the staff salaries  and thus have limited the school to 20 teachers.

- We don't receive any aid to support MHS's infrastructure
- We don't receive any financial grants


Our Stretch Goal:

Here is our dream. $25,000! We are planning to build a computer and science lab and buy at least 50 desks for students.


Did you know?

1. Modern high school was started in 1958

2. Student to teacher ratio then was 25:2 (that is every teacher could attend up to 13 children)

3.In 2015 the student to teacher ratio has decreased to 40:1

4. Modern high school has attained recognition from the government of telangana,India

5.The fees collected from each student is $4 per month

6.The school also provides free mid day meals to the students sponsored by the government of India

7. Students of this schools come from households whose median income range from$25-$50 per month

8. A student from Modern High School,Sheeba Fatima has won the National Main cum Merit Scholarship by competing against  students from all the schools in this area,thus receiving sponsorship for her education from the Government of India for the next 5 years.

9.Each dollar invested in education gives returns of $7-$13


Where will your scholarship contribution go?

We are directly working with management and headmistress of MHS, we have a initial goal of $25000.Any contribution made through indiegogo will directly reach the students of Modern High School.


What else you can do to help..


If you are interested in helping out in other ways you could look at:

  • Share this page on your Facebook, Twitter or GooglePlus account to encourage others to help out.
 https://www.facebook.com/modernhighschoolhyd?fref=ts

story:
Short Summary

This reunion is about you. Your story. Your journey.  In March of 2016 we're having our 20 year reunion party! This reunion can't happen without you.

What We Need & What You Get

We're planning to have the reunion at a centrally located hotel but in order to reserve the space and secure other vendors we need funds to make that happen.

Your donation will go towards setting up the reunion and covering the perks we have listed.

Risks & Challenges

When we say "this reunion can't happen without you", it's not just a marketing line. If we can't raise enough funds to secure even the most modest of locations, we might not be able to have a reunion.

story:
Give the gift of literacy, self-expression and empowerment!

Our Story & The Impact

Notebooks for Peace provides inspirational, customized composition books ("Notebooks for Peace") to youth, aged 15 - 25, in conflict zones by way of youth empowerment-focused NGOs. We work with NGOs to ensure the notebooks reach the desired audience. First stop: The West Bank & Gaza. 

Why is our project important? Each notebook is a gift for a young person in a conflict zone because sometimes they need more than aid - they need inspiration. 


Inspired by the Arab Spring, the notebooks allow youth in unstable environments to express themselves and collaborate; they are tools to help youth organize and mobilize. Notebooks for Peace are an outlet for artistic expression and a tool in the struggle for social change and justice. They empower youth and encourage literacy, self-expression and freedom.


The Need

"At the present time, the West Bank (covering an area of 6,257 Km 2 ) and the Gaza Strip (378 Km 2 ) have an estimated population of 3.15 million Palestinians. About one-third of the population are stu-dents at all levels of education. All through their modern history, Palestinians have always valued education highly."- United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization


"Educational development in Palestine is a unique, rich and challenging experience. Unique because it is one of the very few places in the world, if not the only one, where a Ministry of Education is being built from scratch. Rich because of the eagerness and motivation of the Palestinians to learn from others. Challenging because Palestine is not yet an independent country and is witnessing conflict on a daily basis...However, there is a risk that the conflict will also lead to the complete destruction of educational development work in Palestine so far, as well as the loss of prospects of peace in the country and in the region." - United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization


"Of the approximately seven million Palestinian refugees around the world, more than 650,000 are living in camps along the West Bank and Gaza Strip." - Rich Wiles, Author and Photographic Artist


"An estimated 280 of the 641 schools in Gaza were damaged and 18 were destroyed. More than half of Gazaâ€™s population is under the age of 18 and the disruption to their education, due to the damage caused during Operation â€œCast Leadâ€ (from 27 December 2008 to 18 January 2009) and as a result of the continuing Israeli boycott, is having a devastating impact." - Amnesty International Researcher

View Amnesty International video on the situation in Gaza and the West Bank


The Design

The notebooks use love for art, poetry and international development in way that is truly inspiring. The front cover is a positive social change painting by Kenneth Cruz (he has donated two paintings to this project) and the inside cover includes an inspirational poem by myself, Uraidah Hassani. The top of the page reads: "This is a NOTEBOOK FOR PEACE. This notebook is yours."

Here is a sample of a "Notebook for Peace":

How it Works & What We Need

We will be sending the first shipment of Notebooks for Peace to AMIDEAST's office in the West Bank. AMIDEAST is a leading American non-profit organization engaged in international education, training and development activities in the Middle East and North Africa. Each shipment of notebooks costs between $1,000 - $1,500, taking into account number of books requested and location of NGO, and the notebooks will be manufactured in the United States.

We want to fundraise the entire project through contributions by the global community because we value the message community involvement brings to social change projects. The success of this project depends on people like you! Each pledge of $1 or more receives rewards (see right)! 

How Your Contribution Will Help

Your money will go towards:

  1. Funding the production of 100+ Notebooks for Peace

  2. Funding the shipping of the books to the West Bank

  3. (If we exceed our goal) Funding future Notebooks for Peace projects

    4.  

For your donation, you receive:

  • our eternal gratitude;
  • the lasting knowledge that you gave young people a personalized writing source to encourage their literacy, self-expression and artistic abilities, and encourage their freedom; 
  • a truly inspiring gift that will empower youth who have indomitable will to live and "be the change";
  • your name on the Donor Wall of our blog;
  • a reward equivalent to the size of the donation you gave;
  • and some truly awesome karma headed your way!
    •

Note: This is an on-going project that will continue to ship personalized notebooks to youth in conflict zones on a global scale. Therefore, if we fail to meet our funding goals by the end of the year, your donations are still directed towards this project... because Notebooks for Peace is not a one-time project!

 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    While due to the nature of our project, we are most in need of financial donations, we are delighted when our supporters contribute to our efforts by sharing our project with your friends, family and various other networks.

     

    Please share this project with your network of friends... tweet, post on Facebook, email, embed, what have you! Your clicks & shares increase our "GoGo Factor" on the site and our chances of being featured. So by all means, go ahead! Your clicking & sharing is very valuable to us!

     

    About The Women Worldwide Initiative

    Notebooks for Peace is one of The Women Worldwide Initiative's social change projects.

    The Women Worldwide Initiative connects, inspires and educates women and girls through mentorship programs, social change projects, and an information and inspiration-based online social network. 

    Women Worldwide Initiative believes in: 

    • The power of positive role models and messages to enhance a woman or girl's sense of self-worth and thus drive her towards excellences in all aspects of her life;
    • The ability to affect social change through women and young people;
    • Respect for the worth and dignity of individuals, particularly women and girls; 
    • The inclusion and acceptance of the differences and perspectives of others;
    • A strong connection with local members of the communities we serve, as true change can only come from within.
    • Commitment to the public good; 
    • Accountability to the public; 
    • Transparency, integrity and honesty;
    • Commitment to excellence and to maintaining the public trust.  


    Thank you so much for your interest and support! 


    Uraidah Hassani

    Project Director of Notebooks for Peace

    Founder & Executive Director of The Women Worldwide Initiative

Please share this project with your network of friends... tweet, post on Facebook, email, embed, what have you! Your clicks & shares increase our "GoGo Factor" on the site and our chances of being featured. So by all means, go ahead! Your clicking & sharing is very valuable to us!

story:
What is the project? 

We have started a school and need to raise $4,000 to guarantee teacher benefits for the 2013/2014 school year.

Who are we?

We are an affordable, high-quality school for kindergarten through 8th grade located in San Francisco.

What kind of school?

1. We are progressive.

From our curriculum to our affordable tuition – we fully embrace what it means to be a progressive school.

What is progressive curriculum?

Project-based. Individualized to each child. Hands-on learning. Experiential. 

2. We are affordable.

This means more families have access to high-quality education and this is what our country needs, now. The Schoolhouse has built a solution and will grow as long as we have support.

3. We are a community.

Families make a good school great. Our administration is made up of dedicated parent volunteers. We are proving that a community can build a school from the ground up.

Why this project?

To secure high-quality teachers we need to be able to guarantee teacher benefits. 

Why now?

The education crisis in this country demands we do whatever it takes, and we must implement a variety of new models both inside and outside the current system.

Impact: Take this model and replicate it throughout California to provide high-quality, affordable education to as many families as possible.

Why us? We are proving that an affordable, parent-participation model works – we went from 2 children to 19 children in one year.

We built it, now we need to guarantee it.

How can I connect and find out more about the school?

www.sfschoolhouse.org

http://www.facebook.com/SFSchoolhouse

How can people help?

DONATE. SHARE.

We ask you to make a contribution, no matter how small.  By doing so, you will insure that affordable, high-quality education is an option for more San Francisco families.

You can share this campaign with your collegues, friends, family or anyone who may share in a similar passion (or might like to help).

Our tuition covers what it takes to educate a child – the teacher, a room and basic supplies.

We are fundraising to guarantee teacher benefits for the upcoming 2013/2014 school year. These additional funds are needed to insure the affordability and the future growth of the school.

As the Holidays are approaching, DONATING is a great gift in the season of Giving. What better than a gift to our children.

Thank you, thank you.

Rebecca Dake, Director of School

On behalf of the entire Schoolhouse community.

story:
Why Gardens?
Because gardens produce healthier food. Only 2% of American children eat enough fruits and vegetables, and 1 in 3 American children born after 2000 is at risk for Type II diabetes. A garden is an introduction to the real, healthy food students and families need access to.

Because gardens can help fix America's nature deficit. With more than 80% of Americans living in cities and suburbs, we need to work harder than ever to teach the values of natural processes.

Because gardens are a living laboratory for education. Not just healthy food—a lesson on what producing healthy food requires. Not just exposure to nature—a way for children to literally harvest the fruits of their labor.

A True Seed Investment 
For as little as $10, you can help a community reap all the benefits a garden has to offer. In just 39 days, we plan to raise $2500 per garden; to feed,  teach, and inspire people in each of these 100 communities. Here are a few things our garden plans to do with your donations:

El Camino Real High School is a Model Alternative Designation High School. The goal of the garden is to create a teaching environment by establishing a compost, worm farm and a raised garden. Helping needy students and members of the community with our harvest and providing community service hours required by all students. Loud Jumpy Kids (LJK Cares, Inc.)will be working with the high school to give an added purpose, and provide a unique experience for everyone. (photos and video to follow)

CHECK OUT THE GALLERY FOR IMAGES & VIDEOS

Look Good, Do Good
With every contribution to our garden, donors will receive organic, ethical perks from PACT. Our socks, undies, and t-shirts are produced to high standards of sustainability, with the comfiest organic materials we can find. You'll be giving out of the goodness of your heart, and in return you'll get PACT goodies. It's a win-win situation.

story:
Hello, and thanks for checking out my campaign! My name is Nicole, and I need a lot of help. You see, I’m graduating from San Diego State University in less than a month (woohoo!). I am the first to graduate from college in any of my extended family. I’ve worked my butt off to graduate in four years, as that’s exactly how long I was eligible to receive my full-ride scholarship (which without, I wouldn’t have even been able to go to anything other than a community college). Over the course of these last four years, I’ve had two jobs (working well over 40 hours a week between them) as well as taking 15 to sometimes even 20 units a semester. These jobs helped pay for my wedding to my wonderful husband, as well as paying rent and other bills, and paying off his student loans, which after several years are now down to $30,000. Between my husband’s two jobs and mine we were doing okay, but some poor decisions were made and now he’s making far less than before. We were forced to move into my parent’s house because we had no place to live and couldn’t feed ourselves (all my money was going to our car payment, insurance, phone bills, and paying off student loans).

We are still in this situation today. However, there is hope on the horizon! I have been hired by COKO JUKU, an English school in Japan! I’m getting all emotional as I’m typing this, because this has literally been my life dream. As a child, I always knew I would one day become a teacher. When I took a Japanese course on a whim at SDSU I absolutely fell in love, changed my major to Japanese (I was originally going for Biology) and decided that I would teach in Japan. It’s hard to believe that already paperwork is making its way through Japan so I can fulfill my dream of teaching there.

Everything is set, except for one more obstacle in my way: money. I have recently found out that it is VERY expensive to move to Japan, and right now my husband and I are barely clinging on. As a condition of my employment I have to get a Teaching English as a Foreign Language, or TEFL, Certificate, which already costs way too much ($2750). Then, I have buy plane tickets for my husband and me (at least $1200). Thirdly, I need money for a deposit for my apartment as well as two month’s rent (at least $2500). Finally, as I won’t be getting my first paycheck until about a month and a half after I get there, I need money just to eat ($???)!

            You may ask, with all these expenses, is it even worth it?

100% YES! 

Despite the heavy expense at the beginning, I will be making more by myself (with one job) than my husband and I have ever made together (both working two or three jobs). If my husband can manage to find work out there, then even better! For the first time in what feels like forever, we’ll be able to completely support ourselves. Do you know how great that will feel? AMAZING! Since we’ve been married (and all the time we were together before) we’ve never been able to just live by ourselves as a couple. We’ve always had at least four other roommates, that is, until we had to move back in with my parents. We long to know what it’s like to be a real married couple, just living by ourselves and setting our own rules. In addition, we’ll finally be able to start saving for a house of our own so we don’t have to keep throwing our money into the life-sucking pit of renting. And I mustn’t forget to mention that IT’S MY DREAM FINALLY COMING TRUE AHHHH I CAN’T BELIEVE IT!!!           

One last reason (and honestly, more important to me than my dream) is that my husband and I want to start a family. We’ve been desperately wanting a baby since the day we got married. We are both HUGE family people and we absolutely cannot wait to get started. However, as you can probably tell, we’ve never really been in the situation to have a baby. A house or apartment with four other college-aged people is no place for a baby, and now that we can’t even pay for our own food, now is definitely not the time. Moving to Japan for work will give us the financial stability we’ve been searching for to finally start planning on having a family.

If I don’t get all the money I need, it will first go to getting my TEFL Certificate, as that is an important step if I want to teach at all in the first place. My next step will be to hopefully qualify to take about some loans. I would very much hate to do that, as we’re always paying WAY too much a month to pay back my husband’s student loans, but if that’s the only way to get the money then that’s what I’ll have to do.

Now, how does helping me help society? If I go to Japan to teach, I’ll be a sort of American ambassador to those I’m teaching. I’ll be able to teach those of Japan more about American culture while at the same time portraying a positive example of Americans. In addition, I will be learning more about Japan and their culture. Simple things like the cultural exchanges I’ll be participating in are important steps in creating a global harmony where people of all different backgrounds can understand each other and work together.

If you don’t have the means to help out financially, don’t fret! You can do wonders just by getting the word out! If you like my campaign and want to help by spreading the word, please do so! Post my link in your Facebook, twitter or blog, send some emails, whatever! There are even tools you can use to share my story on Indiegogo, so be sure to check them out!
story_txt:
Hello, and thanks for checking out my campaign! My name is Nicole, and I need a lot of help. You see, I’m graduating from San Diego State University in less than a month (woohoo!). I am the first to graduate from college in any of my extended family. I’ve worked my butt off to graduate in four years, as that’s exactly how long I was eligible to receive my full-ride scholarship (which without, I wouldn’t have even been able to go to anything other than a community college). Over the course of these last four years, I’ve had two jobs (working well over 40 hours a week between them) as well as taking 15 to sometimes even 20 units a semester. These jobs helped pay for my wedding to my wonderful husband, as well as paying rent and other bills, and paying off his student loans, which after several years are now down to $30,000. Between my husband’s two jobs and mine we were doing okay, but some poor decisions were made and now he’s making far less than before. We were forced to move into my parent’s house because we had no place to live and couldn’t feed ourselves (all my money was going to our car payment, insurance, phone bills, and paying off student loans).
We are still in this situation today. However, there is hope on the horizon! I have been hired by COKO JUKU, an English school in Japan! I’m getting all emotional as I’m typing this, because this has literally been my life dream. As a child, I always knew I would one day become a teacher. When I took a Japanese course on a whim at SDSU I absolutely fell in love, changed my major to Japanese (I was originally going for Biology) and decided that I would teach in Japan. It’s hard to believe that already paperwork is making its way through Japan so I can fulfill my dream of teaching there.
Everything is set, except for one more obstacle in my way: money. I have recently found out that it is VERY expensive to move to Japan, and right now my husband and I are barely clinging on. As a condition of my employment I have to get a Teaching English as a Foreign Language, or TEFL, Certificate, which already costs way too much ($2750). Then, I have buy plane tickets for my husband and me (at least $1200). Thirdly, I need money for a deposit for my apartment as well as two month’s rent (at least $2500). Finally, as I won’t be getting my first paycheck until about a month and a half after I get there, I need money just to eat ($???)!
            You may ask, with all these expenses, is it even worth it?
100% YES! 
Despite the heavy expense at the beginning, I will be making more by myself (with one job) than my husband and I have ever made together (both working two or three jobs). If my husband can manage to find work out there, then even better! For the first time in what feels like forever, we’ll be able to completely support ourselves. Do you know how great that will feel? AMAZING! Since we’ve been married (and all the time we were together before) we’ve never been able to just live by ourselves as a couple. We’ve always had at least four other roommates, that is, until we had to move back in with my parents. We long to know what it’s like to be a real married couple, just living by ourselves and setting our own rules. In addition, we’ll finally be able to start saving for a house of our own so we don’t have to keep throwing our money into the life-sucking pit of renting. And I mustn’t forget to mention that IT’S MY DREAM FINALLY COMING TRUE AHHHH I CAN’T BELIEVE IT!!!           
One last reason (and honestly, more important to me than my dream) is that my husband and I want to start a family. We’ve been desperately wanting a baby since the day we got married. We are both HUGE family people and we absolutely cannot wait to get started. However, as you can probably tell, we’ve never really been in the situation to have a baby. A house or apartment with four other college-aged people is no place for a baby, and now that we can’t even pay for our own food, now is definitely not the time. Moving to Japan for work will give us the financial stability we’ve been searching for to finally start planning on having a family.
If I don’t get all the money I need, it will first go to getting my TEFL Certificate, as that is an important step if I want to teach at all in the first place. My next step will be to hopefully qualify to take about some loans. I would very much hate to do that, as we’re always paying WAY too much a month to pay back my husband’s student loans, but if that’s the only way to get the money then that’s what I’ll have to do.
Now, how does helping me help society? If I go to Japan to teach, I’ll be a sort of American ambassador to those I’m teaching. I’ll be able to teach those of Japan more about American culture while at the same time portraying a positive example of Americans. In addition, I will be learning more about Japan and their culture. Simple things like the cultural exchanges I’ll be participating in are important steps in creating a global harmony where people of all different backgrounds can understand each other and work together.
If you don’t have the means to help out financially, don’t fret! You can do wonders just by getting the word out! If you like my campaign and want to help by spreading the word, please do so! Post my link in your Facebook, twitter or blog, send some emails, whatever! There are even tools you can use to share my story on Indiegogo, so be sure to check them out!

story:
My Story

Any graduate program is expensive, and rabbinical school is no exception. Luckily I will have financial aid and loans to help with the cost of tuition and fees, but I haven’t received my financial aid package yet. As you know, tuition is only part of the cost of an education, which will be over $50,000 in my first year alone. I will also be taking a summer intensive course, in preparation for a return to school after many years out of academia. The summer program tuition alone costs over $4400 and unfortunately will not be covered by financial aid. At the moment, I have some money saved to pay for it, but that does not come close to covering both program and living costs.

To make matters even more complicated, my wife, Rachel, is also in graduate school right now. She will be graduating in January, but until then, she will be staying in Baltimore. This means two tuitions and two apartments for summer and the fall semester.

Your gift will give me the freedom to focus on my studies this summer instead of worrying about how I’m going to pay for them. And you’ll be promoting my overall health by keeping me from subsisting on a ramen-based diet.

The greater goal is of course not to complete this summer course, but to become a rabbi. This will be a long and challenging journey that your gift will help me begin.

 

What We Need & What You Get

In addition to the summer tuition, I will be relocating from Baltimore to Los Angeles. This will mean a lot of quality time in the car with my wife, but it also means more expenses just to get started. A portion of the money I receive will go toward these expenses.

The quality time in the car will provide ample opportunity for creative juices to flow. Among other things, Rachel will spend this time writing haikus. With any donation over $18 Rachel will write a haiku (Chai-ku?) just for you as a thank you for your donation.  If you’re feeling even more generous, we have other beautiful perks including handmade original pottery and mezuzah cases.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you’re not able to contribute money, know that you can still help get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word.

story:
Why Suits for Scholars?

When I started my senior year at William and Mary, I remember very clearly my mother taking me shopping for an interview suit.  We went to the Anne Klein outlet in Williamsburg, where she bought me a beautiful burgundy wool skirt suit and a coordinating ivory silk shawl collared blouse.  It was the fall of 1995, and I looked very professional in it - it was a far cry from my typical jeans and plaid flannel shirts.  Every time I put on that suit, I felt confident that I was putting my best foot forward.

My senior year, I also worked in the Office of Career Services, and I witnessed many students' reactions to finding out they had been selected for interviews.

Yes, young alumni, after we parked our dinosaurs outside, we would wait in the hallway of Blow Hall to read a paper list tacked up on a strip of corkboard to see who made the cut.

Each person selected was excited.  But while many took off to start preparing, several would slink inside the office to ask some version of:

"Is it okay if I just wear a nice shirt and pants? I don't own a suit."

One of us working would smile sympathectically and say, "Why don't you try to borrow something.  Maybe from a roommate, or a friend?"  The student would then spend the next few days frantically trying to borrow appropriate clothes in the correct size.  Some were more successful than others.

Ashleigh Brock, Assistant Director at the now-named Cohen Career Center, has a different vision for these students.  When they walk in to the office and say "I have an interview, but... I don't own a suit", her response can be "Why don't you borrow something from us.  Let's go to the closet and see what suits we have in your size." 

I would have loved to have been able to offer that help to students back in 1995.  This is my - and your - opportunity to provide that help to our current students. 

What They Need

Ashleigh Brock has worked hard collecting donated items for Suits for Scholars.  She has suits for men and women in a variety of sizes, some shirts, some shoes.  But she doesn't have items in every size.  The goal is to help every student who walks through the door needing help, not just the ones who are a size X.

By raising funds through indiegogo.com, we can give her the flexibility to shop for the most needed items. Currently, this means women's suits in specific sizes and men's pants in specific sizes.  She also needs a few blazers.  If there is a small remainder after buying the big ticket items, she will use the money for dress shoes, belts, and other accessories as needed.  In other words, if she is able to buy three suits, and there is $30 left over, she will put the money to good use by purchasing a smaller, but still needed, item.

Your cash donation of $10, $25, $50 or more will help her fill these needs.

The Impact

William and Mary students work HARD.  They are well-qualified to add value to employers and be productive citizens.  They are READY. 

The socioeconomic status of their parents should have no bearing on the initial impression they make on interviewers.  None.  Yet the reality is, not every student is equally set up for success regarding interview attire.  And research shows that interviewers form their opinions of candidates within the first 10 seconds of meeting.  For better or for worse, the interview outfit has a large impact on the outcome of the interview.

You have the ability, with your contribution, to help William and Mary students get their first jobs. Let them stand on your shoulders for a day while they make their case to employers. Let them send the message "Hire me" with their appearance. 

Please make your donation now.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share, share, share!  Please e-mail, tweet, post to Facebook!  Many small donations can add up to a big impact, so please help spread the word.

If you would like to donate a new or gently-used accessory or item of clothing, you may send it to:
 
Suits for Scholars c/o Cohen Career Center
College of William and Mary
P.O. Box 8795
Williamsburg, VA 23187

The Bottom Line

If you were like me, and had a family member help you get your first suit, this is an opportunity to pay it forward.

If you could have used this kind of help as a student, please help make the interview process a little easier for the next crop of students.  As you know, the interview process is stressful enough.

Thank you in advance for your contribution.

One Tribe.

Sara Kamp Collins '96 MBA '00

story:
Dear Friends and Family,

 

On February, 15th 2013, I plan to begin my lifelong dream of traveling the world.  My first trip out of the country will involve teaching English in Nepal for five months with the IVHQ Volunteer Program.  For more information on International Volunteer HQ, you are welcome to visit: http://www.volunteerhq.org/

Travelling the world has been a lifelong dream of mine that has always appeared intangible due to limited funds and limited thinking.  I was born and raised in Newark, NJ and once I left NJ for college, I vowed to myself that I would never return.   Well, sometimes, with the Most High Creator, we never know where the Creator will place us.  For the past two years, the Most High Creator has placed me in Newark, NJ.

Living within Newark, NJ for the past two years has been interesting.  When I left N.J. for college, I always carried a strange tinge of guilt for leaving.  I often posed the question to myself, “Why do I get to leave? What makes me so special?”  I guess these two questions constantly streaming through my thoughts led me back to Newark, NJ.  My return to Newark, NJ has allowed me to find answers to my questions:  Why wouldn’t I want to leave?  Life is not to be struggled through.  Life is for living.  I am special and I deserve to get out just like everyone else who has a desire to get out.  There’s nothing wrong with staying, yet, there’s nothing wrong with leaving either.

While in Nepal, I hope to gain a new perspective on life.  I desire to show myself that I am not a victim of my circumstances.  I hope to discover Ashley.  I hope to find answers as to why my mother planted me here.  I hope to write some super dope writings that will inspire many.  I hope to inspire the little black girl that sits on the stoop across from my house, I want to show her that there’s a way out if she desires to get out and it’s okay if she wants to see all of the pictures that this world is capable of creating.  I hope to encourage others within my community to leave their comfort zone and experience life in a way that they desire.   I just wanna live…My intuition has provided me with the green light, so now it’s time to run and never look back.

So, I’m finally allowing myself to think big and to travel the world.  If you would like to support my endeavor to live life by traveling the world, financial donations, prayers and well-wishes are greatly appreciated.   Financial donations will cover program cost and roundtrip flight fair. Please contact me via phone or email if you have any questions.

 

Cut my stem up out this concrete.  Remove my vines from these bricks.  Plant me in a vase of water amongst kindred roses. Seat us elegantly in the mouth of the sun.  We long to shout our shahada to the SUN...

Carpe Diem!  Thank you for your support.

 

Regards,

 

Ashley Woods-Thomas

646.399.2197

asheswoods@aol.com

story:
**UPDATE**

We have raised enough money to fund almost three young people to go up to Sheffield tomorrow! We've already paid for two tickets and will be using the rest to partly reimburse a third young person who paid their own ticket costs. 

If we still get donations:

We will continue to reimburse the rest of the ticket for our third young person. If possible we will try to get another young person to join us before tomorrow's train at 9am!

If we STILL get donations:

We will provide refreshments for our young people on their journey.

And on the off chance we get donations that covers that:

We will put it towards filming call outs of our young people for our Youtube channel to amplify the great things they're doing (when they're not dashing around the country meeting various political leaders!)

Bonus Points!

It was ambitious to try to get 20 young Londoners up to Sheffield. However, We've so far got 4 #youngandprouds ready to catch their train tomorrow. We have joined with Sheffield College and offered 11 students a place at the event too. 

--

We're The YP Collective

Why do we get out of bed every morning?

The YP Collective is about Youth Empowerment, Progression and Confidence.

Celebrating the achievements and contributions young people. Supporting them through our workshops, events, and mentoring so they reach their absolute potential.

Yesterday (Tuesday 13th January 2015) we were invited to the House of Commons to debate with policy makers and MP's on how to improve careers advice. 

This was great. 

As we left we bumped into Ed Miliband! We asked him about his thoughts on young people, his policies and his thoughts on how to improve our youth empowerment.

He invited us to his Youth Manifesto Launch. 

It's in Sheffield on Friday 16th January. 

What's the obstacle? 

How expensive are train tickets?! I mean, it's ridiculous. We have 20 young people so keen to go along to this event but they just can't afford the train fare. The cheaper option of a Megabus or National Express coaches will get there late. 

Can you help our young people get the chance to be involved in politics, have their voice heard, and make an impact on potential future strategy?

It doesn't matter what side you politically swing, our young people deserve the chance to be heard and not have financial constraints in their way.

story:
Dear friends, family, and lovely visitors:

Thank you for checking out my campaign! My name is Hailey and I'm a senior Media Studies major and Linguistics minor at UC Berkeley. For my last semester as a student, I will be headed abroad to study in Florence through the UC Education Abroad Program! 

A bit about me...

I grew up in a small Southern California city called Moorpark before heading up to study at Berkeley. Through my time here the last few years, I've fell in love with the Bay Area, soaked up knowledge in the humanities, and found my music niche at the KALX radio station. In my spare time, I love exploring food & drink and going to concerts.

My goals after I graduate include pursuing music journalism or continuing on in the college radio industry that I've come to know and love. Going abroad to Florence is my last chance to explore a new place and further my education before I have to navigate the daunting professional world and pay off my student debt. 

Why Florence?

Since my family on my mother's side is largely of Italian descent, I've always wanted to get to know the language and the culture more personally. The Florence Language and Culture program that UCEAP offers is the perfect fit! The strong language component will help me become fluent in the Italian language while the culture course, based in food, art, or film, will help me get to know the culture and the city. A directed study course will help me further my studies in media while letting me apply what I've learned about Italian culture. While I'm in Italy, I want to drink up all the history I can, connect with locals, and visit the hometown of my family in the South. 

What I need & How you can contribute

The cost of the program is split into two categories: fees paid to the program (tuition, books, housing) and fees paid out of pocket (airfare, food, incidentals, travel). I'm been lucky enough to receive loans and scholarships to cover fees paid to the program, but now, I'm looking to cover the estimated $4000 I'll need to pay out of pocket through the duration of my program. I've been able to save some money through my job, but not enough to get me through my entire program. Any money I raise will go towards day-to-day necesseties like food and transportation.

Any little bit helps! I'm grateful for any generous donation, and I'm offering perks for certain donation levels. For any donation, you'll receive my undying gratitude :)

If you aren't able to make a monetary donation, you are welcome to spread the word through social media! 

Thank you for taking the time to read through! Grazie e amore for your support.

-Hailey
story_txt: Dear friends, family, and lovely visitors:Thank you for checking out my campaign! My name is Hailey and I'm a senior Media Studies major and Linguistics minor at UC Berkeley. For my last semester as a student, I will be headed abroad to study in Florence through the UC Education Abroad Program! A bit about me...I grew up in a small Southern California city called Moorpark before heading up to study at Berkeley. Through my time here the last few years, I've fell in love with the Bay Area, soaked up knowledge in the humanities, and found my music niche at the KALX radio station. In my spare time, I love exploring food & drink and going to concerts.My goals after I graduate include pursuing music journalism or continuing on in the college radio industry that I've come to know and love. Going abroad to Florence is my last chance to explore a new place and further my education before I have to navigate the daunting professional world and pay off my student debt. Why Florence?Since my family on my mother's side is largely of Italian descent, I've always wanted to get to know the language and the culture more personally. The Florence Language and Culture program that UCEAP offers is the perfect fit! The strong language component will help me become fluent in the Italian language while the culture course, based in food, art, or film, will help me get to know the culture and the city. A directed study course will help me further my studies in media while letting me apply what I've learned about Italian culture. While I'm in Italy, I want to drink up all the history I can, connect with locals, and visit the hometown of my family in the South. What I need & How you can contributeThe cost of the program is split into two categories: fees paid to the program (tuition, books, housing) and fees paid out of pocket (airfare, food, incidentals, travel). I'm been lucky enough to receive loans and scholarships to cover fees paid to the program, but now, I'm looking to cover the estimated $4000 I'll need to pay out of pocket through the duration of my program. I've been able to save some money through my job, but not enough to get me through my entire program. Any money I raise will go towards day-to-day necesseties like food and transportation.Any little bit helps! I'm grateful for any generous donation, and I'm offering perks for certain donation levels. For any donation, you'll receive my undying gratitude :)If you aren't able to make a monetary donation, you are welcome to spread the word through social media! Thank you for taking the time to read through! Grazie e amore for your support.-Hailey

story:
Who We Are...

"I started The GEMS Camp for the girls who are ridiculed for being smart. Girls who do everything they're supposed to do, but have to stay in their environments just because they don't have anywhere else to go. I wanted to give them what was given to me - a quality learning experience that made me curious about the world and compassionate about others in a safe environment." ~ Saki L. Milton, Founder 

The mission of The GEMS Camp - Girls interested in Engineering, Mathematics, and Science, is to build confidence in urban teen girls in five core areas called the five karat gems - Academics, Career, Creativity, Leadership, and Service - so that they will be successful in STEM studies and careers. Since 2010, The GEMS Camp has engaged more than 150 girls in Dallas and Houston in STEM. Our holistic approach to STEM addresses several risk factors that are barriers for traditionally underserved populations, specifically:
  • 95% economically disadvantaged (Title 1 - free or reduced lunch)
  • 100% female
  • 50% Hispanic and African-American
Girls participate in an 8-week intensive Saturday program during the summer where they preview the upcoming school year's content from engaging certified math and science instructors, participate in hands-on project-based lessons, learn from successful women in STEM, complete six hours of community service, and apply practical leadership skills taught by trained, high school and college STEM mentors.

What We are Doing...

The purpose of our student-led campaign is to raise $1,000 from the Dallas site and $1,000 from the Houston site. 90% of the proceeds raised will go to The GEMS (Girls Interested in Engineering, Mathematics, and Science) Camp and the other 10% will be donated to the North Texas Food Bank (DFW area) and the Houston Food Bank. Your gift will greatly help The GEMS Camp continue to serve urban girls in STEM by exposing them to professional women in STEM, purchasing technology, and taking educational field trips.

  • Founded in 1982, the North Texas Food Bank (NTFB) is a Dallas nonprofit hunger relief organization that distributes donated, purchased and prepared foods through a network of more than 250 Partner Agencies in 13 counties. 

  • In fall 2008, the Houston Food Bank merged with End Hunger Network, a Houston-area food rescue organization, thus making more effective use of community resources by working together as one.  In fiscal year 2013-2014, HFB distributed 59 million nutritious meals food and other necessities.


      What We Need & What You Get...

      • The GEMS Camp is a 501(c)(3) tax-exempt organization; therefore, your donation are 100% tax deductible. Great News!
      • If we do not reach our fundraising goal of $2,000, we will still donate 90% to The GEMS Camp and 10% to the North Texas Food Bank and Houston Food Bank.
      • For your $10 donation, we are offering your choice of five (5) different scents of organically-made lip balm packaged in a hand-made Origami box.  Each one is custom hand-made by our GEMS, as they learned about the chemistry of makeup. These lip balms consist of basic ingredients: Vitamin E oil, coconut oil, beeswax, peppermint oil, and lemon oil. The scents are Cherry-Berry, Lemon Cheesecake, Brown Sugar, White Chocolate, and Peppermint (regular, non-scented).


      Your Impact...

      "It's important for me to let others know that their generous gifts will not be wasted. This online, student-led campaign teaches us (GEMS) about business, marketing, sales, finance, product development, communication, and teamwork. These are valuable skills I know we will need in the 21st Century workplace." ~Chenelle E., Houston Gem

      • Help us with the purchase of: Transportation to more exciting STEM-focused field trips throughout the year, instructional materials such as STEM curriculum and tutoring resources, electronic tablets, meals, and uniforms.
      • Last year, we held a start-up scholarship friendraiser called "Be a Gem" for our 2014 summer camps. GEMS Camp t-shirts, badges, armbands, drawstring backpacks were given as perks. Donors gave close to $4,000 towards launching two sites in Texas in Dallas and Houston. 

      • Give your share to show you care!


        Other Ways You Can Help

        • There are several ways you can help without donating money. Tell your friends, family, and coworkers! 
        • Help spread the word easier by clicking on the social media icons.
        • Our fundraising window is July 26 to August 15.

        • Don't forget, "Give your share to show you care!"

These are valuable skills I know we will need in the 21st Century workplace." ~Chenelle E., Houston Gem

Help us with the purchase of: Transportation to more exciting STEM-focused field trips throughout the year, instructional materials such as STEM curriculum and tutoring resources, electronic tablets, meals, and uniforms.


Last year, we held a start-up scholarship friendraiser called "Be a Gem" for our 2014 summer camps. GEMS Camp t-shirts, badges, armbands, drawstring backpacks were given as perks. Donors gave close to $4,000 towards launching two sites in Texas in Dallas and Houston. 

Give your share to show you care!



  Other Ways You Can Help 
There are several ways you can help without donating money. Tell your friends, family, and coworkers! 
Help spread the word easier by clicking on the social media icons.
Our fundraising window is July 26 to August 15.

Don't forget, "Give your share to show you care!"

story:
Our School

Pioneers Baccalaureate School is located in the West Bank city of Nablus (visit us at: www.pioneers.ps). Started at the close of the Second Intifada, our school seeks to build a generation of learners equipped to help move Palestine forward. We do this by offering a very unique bilingual education that focuses heavily on developing critical thinking and communication skills as well as regular academics.

Our school started with 1st-3rd grade and has grown by one grade-level every year. This year, we have begun our first year of 9th grade and our SAT high school program.  We will be proud to graduate our first high school class in 2016. 

We are also proud to bring in a fully native-speaking English staff every year. This drastically improves our students' language, but it also broadens their world view in a very positive way. Our teachers are capable, educated, and dedicated young men and women who devote extreme amounts of time and energy to these students.

Though we are a private school, we are also a non-profit organization. Student tuition covers the basic operating costs of our organization, and we are also proud to offer many scholarships to students from the surrounding refugee camps. 

As we develop, we face myriad challenges due to location and funding. Getting high-level English materials to the West Bank is not easy. Our students begin reading chapter books around 3rd or 4th grade, and we've recycled the few books we have for the past few years. Now, our older students are at a whole new level. They are voracious readers, and their appetite for literature will only get stronger in the coming years. Therefore, it is high time that we provide them the books that they deserve!

Our Project

Nablus is a large, but extremely isolated city. Access to middle and high school level English literature is limited. For many of our students, making the trip to a library in Ramallah is simply not an option. Therefore, our school is the only place these students can obtain books in English. We feel that it is our duty to make more books available. 

Our project goal of $5,000 will cover the cost of classroom sets of 27 novels for our school. This covers many of the books that our students will use in middle school, as well as those that they will need for the next four years of high school. These books will be integrated into our curriculum and will help us achieve our standards for literature and language arts.  The list of books includes (but is not limited to): 

The Westing Game, Tangerine, Maniac Magee, Ender's Game, Harriet the Spy, Matilda, Because of Winn-Dixie, The Adventures of Tom Sawyer, Animal Farm, Fahrenheit 451, The Old Man and the Sea, Hamlet, Grapes of Wrath, and Heart of Darkness. 

Obviously these books alone will not achieve the requirements of our program, but it is a wonderful start!

We will be purchasing the books in bulk from The Reading Warehouse, and shipping them (for free!) to a U.S. location. We will then ship them to the West Bank (via Israel). The customs fees and taxes, as well as the shipping costs, are calculated into our goal. 

In the event that we do not reach our goal we will purchase as many classroom sets as funding allows, focusing on our immediate needs for the rest of this year. Any amount that you can contribute will go towards getting us these books, and we thank you in advance for your help! 

For more detailed information about our book lists or projected costs, please email us at: earlypioneers@gmail.com

The Impact

Taking the opportunity to donate a book to any child is a valuable thing. However, by donating to this campaign you are putting English reading material in the hands of a student who would not otherwise be able to find it. 

These books will be invaluable to us as our school moves forward. These classroom sets will be used year after year, and will continually challenge and advance our students' learning. With your one-time donation, you will be part of a library legacy within Pioneers Baccalaureate School. 

Please check out our "perks" (located on the right), and get on board!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is in a position to donate at this time. We would also fully appreciate your help in spreading the word about our school and our project. By sharing our story with people that you know can help, you are doing us a wonderful service. Thank you!

story:
"Education is the most powerful weapon which you can use to change the world." - - Nelson Mandela.

Become a part of our efforts to invest in a poor child's education and help Change the World!  If our video moves you; if you agree that education is a  solid investment; that this project benefits all of us (because educated, happy, confident children really CAN change our world for the better), then please CONTRIBUTE what you can; and SHARE this Campaign with your networks!

OUR GOAL:

Our overall goal is to raise $50,000 to send 25 poor children to high school in Jamaica for 2013-2014 school year.  This Indiegogo Campaign is part of the overall fundraising effort.  Every dollar counts!  A $5 gift provides lunch for one child for one day.  A $20,000 gift funds 13 students!

WHO WE ARE:

CARIBBEAN EDUCATION FOUNDATION, INC. (CEF) is a registered 501(c)(3) tax-exempt, nonprofit organization based in the United States.  We are dedicated to helping poor children receive meaningful access to quality education.  Our current mission country is Jamaica. 

WHAT IS THE PROBLEM?

Public High Schools are NOT FREE in Jamaica!  High school starts in Grade 7. It costs at least $1,500 U.S. to send 1 child to public high school each year.  Children must pay school fees, textbooks, transportation and lunch, including the usual uniforms and school supplies!  The minimum wage is $50 U.S. per week for a 40 hour work week or $200 U.S. dollars per month. 

As you can imagine, it is practically impossible for working poor families to regularly send their children to high school.  The dismal situation is depriving an entire generation of brilliant children of meaningful access to education.

HIGH SCHOOL - A CRITICAL PROBLEM (Jamaica Education Report by the Ministry of Education)

  • Over 30% of urban youth and 50% of rural youth have little to no High School attendance.  
  • Low attendance rates are due to a lack of bus fare to attend school.
  • 50% of students are below their grade level. 
  • By Grade 9, hundreds of thousands of students, especially boys, cannot read or write.
  • Chronic poor attendance at all levels is the major cause of the high illiteracy rate, as well as a lack of text books to learn lessons taught.
  • 80% of secondary graduates did not have the requisite qualification for meaningful employment or university programmes.

WHAT HAVE WE DONE?

Since its inception in April 2007, CEF has awarded over 40 student scholarships in excess of $50,000 U.S. dollars to brilliant, poor children to attend school.  Our Paul Bogle Scholarships students' pay school fees, textbooks, school supplies, transportation and lunch.  Scholarships are based on academic merit and financial need.  Scholarships are renewed each year, if the student attends school regularly and maintains good grades.

Our goal is to help 25 children go back to school in September 2013!  CEF currenlty has 18 children who need scholarship renewals, so they may return to high school in September 2013 and enter Grades 8, 9, and 10.  We have 7 new students who need to enter Grade 7. 

CEF's President, Nikiki Bogle, Esq. giving Ravorn his Paul Bogle Scholarship Certificate - -  Awards Dinner in Kingston, Jamaica,  September 2010

_______________________________________________________________________________

MORE ABOUT RAVORN:                              Scholarship Years: 2010, 2011, 2012


Ravorn lives in the inner-city slum of Riverton City, Kingston, Jamaica, with his mother and siblings.  Riverton City is a landfill - - a garbage dump, that is not habitable for human beings to live in.  Since Grade One, Ravorn had to attend school numerous times without lunch. Many days he had to walk a long journey to school, because his mother had no money for bus fare.

Duhaney Park Primary was streamed where bright students are placed at the top and thereafter in descending order.  Ravorn was placed in the fourth stream, and therefore not expected to pass his exam for a top high school.

Ravorn says, "I proved everyone wrong when I passed for Calabar High School!"  He obtained 96% in Mathematics and 90% in Science on the Grade Six Achievement Test (GSAT).  Ravorn received high awards in Primary School including: Most Outstanding Student in His Class, English Language, Science, Religious Education and Most Disciplined Student.

Ravorn will be entering Grade 10 at Calabar High in Sept. with your help!

Ravorn would like to attend University and pursue a Degree in Business.

_______________________________________________________________________________

CEF awards scholarships to poor children who are unable to attend high school, because families are cannot pay school fees and other required school related costs. 

CEF's Paul Bogle Scholarship Awards Dinner - - in Kingston, Jamaica, September 2010   L-R: Coya, (Wolmer's Girls High), Trevisa (Morant Bay High), Amoy (Ardenne High), Sarah (Immaculate High), Ravorn (Calabar High), Travis (St. George's College).

Every day, thousands of children like Ravorn are on the streets instead of attending high school. On the surface, it may appear that these 12-year old children do not wish to attend school, but that is farthest from the truth. Many of the children are brilliant and passed their high school entrance exams (GSAT), but are unable to attend public high schools, because destitute or working poor families cannot afford school costs. 

CEF Scholars with our President, Nikiki Bogle, Esq. at Emancipation Park - Kingston Jamaica, May 2013    FRONT, L-R: Christopher (Ardenne High), Amoy (Ardenne High), Garth (Kingston College); BACK, L-R: Andre (Jamaica College), Sarah (Immaculate High), Ravorn (Calabar High), Shamarie (St. George's College), Coya, (Wolmer's Girls High)

WAYS TO HELP

Please Make a Contribution Today!  For only $25 you can help 1 child with transporation to school for 1 month.

Become a CEF Education Ambassador for $1,500 and Adopt-a-Student!

Please tell everybody you know about our Campaign: your family, co-workers, friends.  Ask them to tell everybody they know! POST our Campaign on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, and even your own website. Send out an email, call your family, friends and colleagues!

Slip a note under your boss's door - maybe the company you work for would like to sponsor us as a charitable tax write-off? Ask friends to donate!

Please visit our website at www.educatechild.org for more information.

Educate one child, Empower a community...and Transform our world.

One Love,

CEF Team.

Please visit our website at www.educatechild.org for more information.
Educate one child, Empower a community...and Transform our world.
One Love,
CEF Team.

story:
About Staros

Staros will be the first U.S. web-based electronic points reward system that will unify, digitize, and optimize schools' positive behavioral reward programs.  Teachers will discretionarily award Staros points (electronically) to students that demonstrate positive behaviors (defined by the school).  Students will then redeem these points, using their Staros rewards card, to purchase products/prizes (generated by schools and partnering retailers) of their choice.  Staros will also offer, for the first time, analytical behavioral reporting aimed to help inform and empower teachers, admins, students, and parents.  Since Staros is a form of currency, students will be exposed to key financial principles, such as saving, consuming, interest, pooling, and donating.  Financial literacy will be addressed but with a smaller emphasis.



Our Mission

Improve K-12 education.

What We Need

We're looking to raise $10,000 which will be used to build a demo we can take to investors and customers.  Our stretch goal is $50,000, which would allow us to build the first working prototype.  Every donation, big or small matters! 

What You Get

If you work in K-12 education or are the parent of a child, and would like to see this program in your school, we will provide this service free for one year to each donator's affiliated school.  There is no minimum donation to receive this perk! 

Please keep in mind that during the initial launch, we may not have the resources to launch to many schools simultaneously.  Therefore, at the onset, preferences will be given to those with larger donations.  However, as we grow and build the resources needed to serve more customers, your donations will not be forgotten and we will honor our commitment and provide this product free of charge for one year.  

The Impact

The most obvious impact of your donation is to help launch a start-up.  However, it extends far beyond that.  Your donation will help help tackle a much bigger challenge facing the U.S. -- improving the quality of K-12 education.  If you're passionate about improving education, rest assured your donations will go to work towards that noble cause.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please pass our campaign to friends, family, educators, and others that might be interested in donating!


About The Founder


Over the past 12 years, Richard Essig has held a variety of commercial leadership roles in the healthcare industry spanning R&D, sales, marketing, business development, and recently accepted a role in Johnson & Johnson's leadership development program.  For the past year, Richard served as a marketing advisor to the CEO of an award-winning online healthcare start-up, Symcat.  Richard is also an adjunct faculty member in the business department at his alma mater, West Chester University of PA.  Having been voted by his MBA peers as most likely to give a TED talk, people quickly identify with Richard’s passion for erudition.  Richard is the first in his family to earn a college degree, and understands as well as anyone, the importance of a great education.  Richard has a B.S. in microbiology, M.Ed. in secondary education, M.S. in finance, and an MBA - emphasis in entrepreneurship, from The Fuqua School of Business at Duke University.

story:
** To donate by check please email: holder08@live.missouristate.edu all checks will be made to Chi Sigma Alpha 

Short Summary

We are a small group of graduate students at Missouri State University studying Student Affairs Higher Education trying to raise money for a new non-profit called Student Affairs Cancer Foundation. This organization provides grants up to $750 for Student Affairs professionals and/or their family to use to help manage the cost of having cancer. I am sure already you are wondering what is Student Affairs? 

Surprisingly enough you to or someone you know have interacted with a member of this field. We are the learning outside the classroom on a college campus. We are you or your children's residence halls where you rest you head. We are the programs that allows you to connect to new people and ideas. We are your organizations that build your resumes while creating lifelong memories and relationships. We are the first people you encounter during your application, orientation, registration and move in process.

What We Need & What You Get

Missouri State University SAHE program would like to work towards the goal of raising $1000.  SAHE has pronounced their goal of reaching out to Springfield school districts, local colleges/universities, and businesses, as well as community members in order to achieve their fundraising goal. We spend our lives trying to make your college experience meaningful and help you in any way we can. Now we need your help to fund our cause in helping our friends, families, and colleagues survive cancer.

•  We want to raise at least $1000 but hope for more

•  We will use all the money to donate to the organization minus the cost of this site.


The Impact

Cancer has affected the lives of millions. It is the hope of MSU SAHE program to help promote and raise awareness towards the cause, while pairing efforts with the Student Affairs Cancer Foundation. The sole purpose of this mission is to help aid Student Affairs professionals and their families who are affected by cancer. These fundraising efforts carry the opportunity to build a bridge of hard work and dedication towards the fight and management of cancer. Join the fight.

Cancer is expensive and impacts all of us one way or another. This organization provides grants up to $750 for Student Affairs professionals and/or their family to use to help manage the cost of having cancer. 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are numerous ways that anyone can be of assistance.

·  Donation of t-shirt costs, products and/or production companies

·  Assistance with marketing

·  Sharing the MSU SAHE Cancer Foundation Page

·  Speaking with students, peers, and family members and education them on the cause.

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

•  Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

•  Share this page

•  Visit our info booths in the MSU Plaster Student Union on 10/28-10/30

And that’s all there is to it.
