story:
GLOW Mongolia

While women are starting to play a larger role in Mongolian society, it is important that more women from the countryside gain confidence at a young age. It is more difficult to overcome certain expectations for women outside of UB (the capital). I want to teach my students that they can have a career. Confident young women are capable of anything! They need support from teachers like me to gain the strength they will need to overcome many obstacles in their future.

  Our vision is to see stronger confidence in young women in Mongolia, which will lead to greater gender equality and a stronger society in general.

  Goals:  While the United Nations has declared gender equality a human right, the world still faces a persistent gender gap. Global trends show that women typically have fewer opportunities for economic participation, less access to education, greater health risks, and less political representation. As such, our goal is women's empowerment, defined by US Peace Corps as, "increasing a woman's access to opportunities, control over her own life, and ability to effect change." Starting with trainings at a young age is essential to attain such gender equality. Our program will focus exclusively on female youth in grades nine through twelve.

  Objective:  After completing one year of GLOW Club (Girls Leading Our World), our Mongolian students will have gained confidence and developed skills important for their future lives. Our Mongolian students will demonstrate their new skills and abilities by teaching at a cross-cultural two week summer camp with 10-20 American high school students. 


What We Need & What You Get

The Basics: We need $320 per Mongolian student for this project. We would like to include 25 Mongolian high school girls, which means we need a minimum of $8,000. 

The Project includes a Speaker Series, Health and Life Skills classes, and hands-on projects designed to build confidence and expand the student's skill sets. It will continue throughout an entire school year, meeting 2 hours a week. The project will culminate in a two week "camp," where our students will host 10-20 American high school girls, teaching them some of the new skills learned throughout the year. We believe that this unique cross-cultural "camp" will inspire the 25 girls in this program to share their experiences and new skills with other Mongolian students.

The Project Break-Down:

  • Speaker Series: "Powerful Women in Our Community"

Province Vice Governor

Education Department: Director of Foreign Language Methodology

Police Department

World Vision: Province Director

BookBridge: Province Manager

  • Health Education Classes: "The Largest Issues Facing Mongolian Youth"

Sex Education

Healthy Eating

Exercise

  • Life Skills Classes: "A Jump-Start on Life"

Project Design, Implementation, & Management

Sewing

Business Manners

Writing a Resume/CV

Writing a Cover Letter/ Application Essay

  • Hands-On Projects: "You Can!"

Traditional Mongolian Deel Making

Knitting a Hat

Card Making & Origami

The Basics Of Healthy Cooking

Community Clean-Up

The Cost Break-Down:

  • $2,000 - Sewing Machines for the project and to be kept for use in Technology classes at our public school
  • $115 per Mongolian Student - Materials for the Hands-on Projects throughout the school year
  • $130 per Mongolian Student - Food, housing, and other resources for the 2 week camp
  • The cost for all of the Speaker Series, Health, and Life Skills classes will be covered through donations from the local community (about 15% of the total project cost)
  • The American Students will cover their own costs.

If we don't reach our goal we will have to limit the number of Mongolian girls that can participate in this unique program. If we are able to surpass our goal, we would like to include more girls in this project. 


About Our School and Project Staff:

The 1st School of Bulgan has about 1,500 students from grades 5 to 12 and is associated with a kindergarten that covers the younger grades. More than 200 of our students live in the dormitory, as their families work as traditional herders and live too far from any school district for them to commute. We have approximately 80 teachers and 15 staff members. The Foreign Language Department consists of 10 teachers.

Buyanbat, our lead English Language teacher for this project, has been teaching at our school for 10 years. She is the homeroom teacher for 11g class and works very hard to improve the English education at our school and at the Learning Center that she runs in the community. She is very excited about the opportunities for change that this GLOW project can offer and hopes to institute a similar project the following year, as well, if this project is a success.

Our American Peace Corps Volunteer (PCV), Chris Corvetti, has shown great energy, creativity, and enthusiasm in promoting and helping to design this project. She graduated from Emma Willard School in 2007 and St. Lawrence University in 2011. She will be leaving our school in July of 2016 to pursue her Master's Degree, so now is our only chance to get this project started. Doing any project in Mongolia can be difficult, but with the help of our PCV, I believe that this project will be a great success. 

Your contribution will forever improve the life of young Mongolian women. Thank you for your support!

story:
The root of our vison

Rafiki was founded about one year ago by a young Norwegian, Hennie Kongsøre. In 2013 she explored the beauty of Tanzania. As part of getting to know the people and the culture, she discovered a huge lack of quality education and the struggle of everyday life in the small town of Bagamoyo.

An educational trip led to the meeting with the organization Mtoto Mchoraji. This gave her hope for the children. At the Center the kids were provided with educational fundings and support; from art, English and mathematic lessons to nutritious food and care. Unfortunately, due to lack of funding and non-ownership of the land. The Community Center was demolished. 

Returning back to Norway, Hennie decided to help the Community by all means possible. This specific course, was the inspirational reason for the foundation of Rafiki. After the plan was set in motion, the first big step was purchasing land with the cooperation of Mtoto Mchoraji.  

To keep the project going and to continue to create possibilities - YOUR contribution is crucial to make an essential impact on the children's future!

Your contribution

100% of all donations goes directly to finish the Community Art Center and support the children. 0% goes to the administration as all our board members work as volunteers. 

Achievement so far

Two buildings that are almost complete including:

- Dance stage and a platform used for dance/music lessons and performances.

- Building with several bathrooms, toilets, changing-rooms, bedrooms and an office. 

- Total Expenses are approximately: $25.000   

- All expenses are from private donations, events, shows, sale etc. 

Achievement for reach

- Final instalments of the bathrooms, toilets, walls and windows. 

- Remaining buildings for fine-art and educational lessons. 

- Fine-art materials and equipment for the classes. 

- Total remaining expenses are approximately: 8.000$

Other ways to contribute
There are other optional ways to get involved. Please feel free to get in touch with us and become part of our Rafiki family.

story:
If you know me at all, you'll know that I am living my dreams in two main ways:
* that I am a freelance Swedish - English translator, earning a pittance, but doing a job that I studied 5 years at university for, and one that I truly adore.
* that I have started learning BSL. I am currently taking my Level 2 exams, and all being well, I've totally nailed it. This is my hobby, yet another linguistic passion, and I just love the learning process for this visual-only language.

My issue is that Level 3 BSL, beginning in October, is an insane cost of £985 (including exam fees).
There is no way - on my meagre wage - that I can even make the monthly instalment payment plan the company are offering, much less pay it all in one go.
I have no other financial avenues to explore, and I would lose a lot of what I've learned if I were to defer the course for a year or two.

So - for my 34th (eek!) birthday on 6th August, I would like to request the following:
In lieu of gifts, a drink in the pub, a bottle of gin/wine/whatever my dear friends may have considered, I'm humbly asking that you please divert your kindness and generosity into funding and helping me continue my sign language dream.
Even a chunk taken off will really help me keep my head above water and keep doing what I love.

Level 3 will allow me to gain sufficient knowledge and awareness to be able to use my skills to help the d/Deaf community in some way. There is shockingly little support, even in this day and age, for the d/Deaf community, not to mention the horrific treatment they suffered in days gone by. I can't wait to be sufficiently qualified to make a real difference; in fact, I have already been approached to volunteer interpret for d/Deaf attendees at Nine Worlds Geekfest Convention in August 2016 (which is coincidentally on my 35th birthday!)

Thank you all so much in advance.

story:
I am ecstatic to be continuing my journey as a teacher at Green Valley Elementary in a 2nd grade classroom! This past year I had the honor to work with the students at GVE in my Student Teacher Residency and it has been such an eye-opening experience. I was amazing to watch students, many of which face adversity, hardship and often discrimination, grow and learn with resilience and fervor. I have truly gleaned so much from these students and I know that in the upcoming years I will continue to learn and grow from the relationships we create.


I believe that it is my duty to build a classroom that will allow my students to thrive. I hope to create a joyful classroom where students are able to have access to resources and materials that will spark their imagination and challenge them to engage, explore and evaluate what they are learning.

   
NOW THIS IS WHERE YOU COME IN! Because this is my first year in my own classroom and the money allocated by the district for classroom supplies is limited, I will be starting from the ground up. Whatever you are able to donate will assist immensely in helping me set up my classroom. The funds that I collect will go toward classroom supplies, student library books, resources materials, resources for bilingual learners, and organizational materials.

 
Thank you so much for generosity! Your donations will make it possible for me to create a classroom where students were excited to come each morning and are given the opportunities to cultivate their love for learning.

Check this out, This is what I aspire to be for my students

https://www.ted.com/talks/rita_pierson_every_ki...

The funds that I collect will go toward classroom supplies, student library books, resources materials, resources for bilingual learners, and  organizational materials.   Thank you so much for generosity! Your donations will make it possible for me to create a classroom where students were excited to come each morning and are given the opportunities to cultivate their love for learning.   Check this out, This is what I aspire to be for my studentshttps://www.ted.com/talks/rita_pierson_every_ki...

story:
With our project we give, not only the schools in Uganda, the possibility to create quickly and promptly the certificates. The time saved can be used effectively for teaching. The latency of the students (called "lausy weeks") is omitted. The actual vacation time for the students will be extended. Costs for pupils, students and schools can be reduced.


Für die deutsche Beschreibung bitte hier klicken!


Prolog

Some years ago I got in touch with my fiancee Gladys, who is ugandan. At this time she lived with her single mother, an aunt, a niece and her five siblings in a small house with only two rooms. Her brother Kabali had just finished high school successfully. Later, after many letters, emails and some phone calls, I was invited to visit Uganda. Fortunately at least I accepted and I visited the first time in my life Uganda in September 2011.

My first stay in Uganda was really a great experience. At first I was shocked by great poverty in Uganda. I realised that the average annual income in Uganda is $ 600 a year. After that, I soon realized that much of Uganda is under construction. But due to poverty, there is little progress. My special attention was at Uganda's school system, as most of Gladys' siblings are still going to school. Uganda's School system is totally different to the german school system.


After high school, Gladys was gifted with a small income. Her job was paid with a salary about only 200, - dollars / month... She managed to join Makerere University Business School and pay her tution fees. Before she had completed, her brother Kabali had to join University too. Therefore, Gladys had to stop her studies and started paying the tution fees for her brother. Beside that she had to pay for their house rent, feeding her other siblings and for their school fees.


During Kabali's time at the University, tution fees were increased and Gladys could not manage to pay it anymore. Thank god, I was informed in time and I was able to help and contribute to his tution fees and support the family. This brought joy and happiness to the family. With my help Kabali could finish his studies.


The school system and costs

In Uganda, there is a compulsory education. Every ugandan has the right to go to school for seven years. A school year is divided into three terms, starting in January. Usually, all children start in the nursery school. This is similar to Kindergarten and / or preschool. Primary school is the next. Followed by the secondary school with six secondary classes starting with S1. The "O" level, you are finished with the completion of the class S4 (comparable middle school) and the "A" level ends with the completion of the class S6 (Abitur). After this, schooling is completed.

After finishing S4 vocational training will start, if you pay for it. After finishing exame for S6 with success you can join university.

In Uganda only children whose parents have good financial income are able to attain good education and attend schools, especially in good standard private schools. 

The cost for the parents include school fees, accommodation, food, school clothes, school supplies and transportation. School fees range between 250,000 and 1,000,000 Ush per Term ( $ 100 - $ 400), depending if there is a puplic or private school.

Some examples: The salary of a primary school teacher is about 150,000 Ush. A teacher of a private secundary school is abount 350,000 Ush, a good payed office worker receives about 700,000 Ush. A litre of gasoline costs about 3,250 Ush.


The Problem

Even now, at the end of each term, students have to wait for their report cards up to three weeks. This is really a problem. 

Since many teachers write the repots by hand,  it takes a lot of time for the teachers to complete students' reports. Most classes have up to 100 students, Therefore, teachers need up to two - three weeks to write all report cards.

Kabali told me that this is called "lausy weeks" and it is hated by the students. During this time, schools incur unnecessary costs for food, accommodation, electricity, water and security most especially for boarding schools. This applies to about 20% of all students (approximately 8,500,000) !

We calculated all together in average costs about $ 55 per student and year. These extra costs are charged to the parents and / or families as a part of school fees.

Kabali came up with an idea to create reports online, so that schools, students and parents can access thier results online at the end of every school term. We made a brain storming how to counteract this. It was christmas 2012 and after a few days we had a concrete idea and set about solving the problem. We still had no idea how extensive our project will be. But, it was the birth of "MyReport".


MyReport - the Software


Upon my return to germany, I spoke with a programmer I knew. I could win him for our project. Since the beginning of January 2013 Gerald worked for free on the development and programming of the required software.

In early May 2013 we had a first version ready and I could visit the first schools along with Kabali. In two months, we visited more than eighty private secondary schools. The schools were interested, but had lots of additional ideas and wishes.

This meant that our online solution was not sufficient.

Since then we have continuously developed and updated our software. Now there is not only an online service, but also a print service for printing of certificates and report cards, an upload service for audit and holiday work, a communication service for teachers - parents / students and a website service for schools that still have no homepage.


Starting a business

To ensure that everything is legal, Gladys and Kabali registered Myreport Uganda Limited. Below is our Certificate of Incorporation.


Targets

We want to:

Support schools, to reduce costs ( in average, from $ 11 down to $ 3  per student  and per year ! ) and relieve teachers. We want to encourage schools to support students with the inserted money and invest money in school equipment and provide scholarships. In this way we can help to bring more and better education along for the school children in Uganda and  later on in other african countries.


Through our project, we achieve the following objectives:

  • Reduce costs for schools and families
  • more class time for schools/students/pupils
  • Timely issue of uniform products
  • Longer holidays for students
  • Relief for families

With your support, we can:

  • further improve our sofware
  • organize presentations to several schools at once
  • give a jobs to local programmers / IT technicans
  • conduct briefings for teachers in the use of the software
  • create further jobs
As a next step, it is planned to open a small office in Kampala, where we can work at the project, doing the necessary work and receiving visitors.
Later on, small nationwide offices can support schools that have no IT-lab where they can pick their printed report cards. 

Software presentation
We are going two ways to present our sofware.
One way is to present our software to the management ( headteachers, directors and IT-teachers ) of the visited schools. It is a big problem to get an appointment. You have to visit them mostly several times to get this date and this means to take a lot of time and money.
The other way is to organize presentations. In November 2013 we organized our first big presentation. Therefore we invited 30 private secondary schools to send their representatives to Kampala Kolping Hotel at the 16th November 2013. 
Unfortunately end of year exams were running and there have been only a few representatives. Any way it was very exciting, a great experience and we have learnt a lot.
Presentation at Kolping Hotel Kampala, 2013-11-16
Preparings

Welcome by General Director Kabali Samson

Presentation software "MyReport"


Very attentive school representatives


The final picture of our first presentation



Office required - urgently
We have to set up an office because the school representatives have always asked us where our office is. They do not believe that we work at home. Unlike in Germany, in Uganda an office at home is not taken serious and not considered as an office.
We had not planned to pay extra money for an office as we had hoped to work at home. Up to now we have spend more than 4,500 hours with hard work (equivalent to over $ 460,000) for software development, preparation of documentation and manuals for users, and more. In addition, costs of flights, transportation, accommodation, meals, the presentation at the Kolping Hotel, etc. We want to, and we will continue our way, in any case.

Expected Costs
After a research, we came up with a budget for expected costs as shown below:
Running costs for an office (approx.):  $/month
 rental

200,00
 power  20,00
 water

7,00
 
One time equipment for the office (approx.):

$
 office Equipment

4500,00
 2 PC / laptop, two printers

2200,00
 office Supplies

1200,00
 
Personnel costs for employees (approx.):

$/month
 office worker

300,00
 driver

275,00
 
Transportation and travel costs (approx.): $/month
 rent for a car

275,00
 fuel

275,00
 
Advertising (approx.):

$
 Flyers / Proposal for Schools 150,00
 Business Cards 100,00
 
4 presentations with about 80-100 school representatives

$/Present.
 Rent for a Meeting room / hall 350,00

 catering for representatives

 350,00

All together there will be costs, for the first two years of about $ 50,000. Of course, we hope to win the first schools as customers during the year 2015.

If we receive more support as needed, the funds are fully incorporated into our social engagement.


Our objective economic and social intention

It is planned that the use of My Report will cost the schools in the base version not more than maximum $ 0.50 - 1.00 per student per year. So that we can cover the running costs and still earn some profit.

We will continue our way (see above), therefore we believe in our success, that we will be able in future , to support childrens, pupils & students. That we are able to support families to give their children an education and /or to learn a profession.

Further on we are working on other social projects to help the people in Africa. We also want to enable children from poor families to attend school and support students.

Thank you for reading. We would be very pleased to welcome you as one of our donators.

Siegfried Brandt

Deutsche Projektbeschreibung

Mit unserem Projekt geben wir nicht nur Schulen in Uganda die Möglichkeit schnell und einfach Zeugnisse und Bescheinigungen für ihre Schüler und Studenten auszustellen. Die eingesparte Zeit kann effektiver zum Lehren genutzt werden. Die Wartezeiten der Schüler und Studenten ("lausy weeks" genannt) fallen weg. Die tatsächliche Ferienzeit für die Schüler würde sich verlängern. Kosten für Schüler, Studenten und Schulen können reduziert werden.



Vorwort

Ende Januar 2011 lernte ich meine jetzige Verlobte Gladys kennen. Gladys stammt aus Uganda und lebte dort zusammen mit ihrer alleinerziehenden Mutter, einer Tante, ihren fünf Geschwistern und einer Nichte in einem kleinen Haus mit zwei Zimmern. Zu ihren Geschwistern gehört auch ihr Bruder Kabali, welcher zu der Zeit gerade die Highschool mit Erfolg beendet hatte. Nach längerem Brief und Emailkontakt sowie später einigen Telefongesprächen besuchte ich Gladys in Uganda.
Mein erster Aufenthalt in Uganda war ein ganz tolles Erlebnis. Zuerst erschütterte mich die große Armut. Das durchschnittliche Jahreseinkommen liegt bei ca. 600 Dollar im Jahr. Danach erkannte ich bald, dass in Uganda vieles im Aufbau ist. Aber bedingt durch die Armut gibt es nur kleine Fortschritte. Besondere Aufmerksamkeit erregte das Schulsystem, da die Geschwister von Gladys alle noch zur Schule gehen. Es unterscheidet sich deutlich vom Deutschen Schulsystem.

Gladys begann nach der Highschool ein Studium an der Makerere Universität of Business in Kampala. Als sich ihre Eltern trennten, schaffte es ihre Mutter nicht die Studiengebühren aufzubringen. Deshalb musste Gladys ihr Studium abbrechen und nahm Mitte 2010 eine Arbeit an. Mit ihrem Einkommen in Höhe von 200,- Dollar/Monat ernährt sie jetzt die Familie, zahlt die Miete und unterstützt die Geschwister bei den Schulgebühren.

Gladys, die auch ihren Bruder Kabali unterstützt, ist damit an die Grenze ihrer Möglichkeiten angelangt. Beinahe hätte Kabali nicht seinen Abschluss machen können. Hier konnte ich zum Glück unterstützen und bekam so einen sehr guten Einblick in das bestehende Schulsystem.

Das Schulsystem und Kosten
In Uganda gibt es eine Schulpflicht bis zur Klasse 7. Ein Schuljahr ist in drei Terms unterteilt und beginnt in Januar. Üblicherweise starten alle Kinder in der Nurseryschool. Dieses ist vergleichbar mit Kindergarten und / oder Vorschule. Es folgt die Primary School, vergleichbar Grund- / Hauptschule, bis zur 7. Klasse. Danach folgt die Secundary School mit sechs weiterführenden Klassen beginnend mit S1. Das "O" Level beendet man mit Abschluß der Klasse S4 ( vergleichbar Mittlere Reife ) und das "A" Level endet mit Abschluß der Klasse S6 ( Abitur ). Damit ist diese schulische Ausbildung beendet. Mit Abschluß S4 beginnt dann das Arbeitsleben mit Besuch einer "Vocationalschool" vergleichbar mit einer Berufschule, wenn denn die Eltern dieses finanzieren können. Allerdings entspricht das nicht unserem Dualen Ausbildungssystem ! Wer es schafft die Studiengebühren zu bezahlen hat mit erfolgreichem Abschluß des "A" Level die Chance ein Studium zu beginnen. Die übliche Studiendauer beträgt zwei Jahre. Man sollte aber daran denken, dass nur Kinder deren Eltern über die entsprechende finanziellen Mittel verfügen, der Schulbesuch möglich ist, Dann kann man sogar eine der vielen guten privaten Schulen besuchen. Die Kosten für die Eltern setzten sich aus Schulgebühren, Unterkunft, Verpflegung, Schulkleidung, Schulmaterialien und Transport zusammen. Sie liegen je nach Schule und Level zwischen ca. 250.000 Ush und über 1.000.000 Ush je Term. Ungerechnet sind das ca. 100 bis über 400 Dollar. Einige Beispiele: Das Gehalt eines Grundschullehrers beträgt ca. 150.000 Ush. Ein Lehrer einer privaten Secundary School liegt bei ca, 350.000 Ush; Eine gute Bürokraft erhält ca. 700.000 Ush. Ein Liter Benzin kostet ca. 3.250 Ush.

Das Problem
Am Ende eines jeden Terms sollten die Schüler ihre Zeiugnisse erhalten. Und hier gibt es ein großes Problem. Viele Schule, bis auf wenige Ausnahmen eigentlich fast alle, erstellen die Zeugnisse noch von Hand. Bei Klassengrößen von bis zu 100 Schülern ist es somit kein Wunder, dass Lehrer bis zu zwei Wochen brauchen um das zu bewerkstelligen. Von Kabali habe ich erfahren, dass dieser Zeitraum " lausy weeks " genannt und von den Schülern gehaßt wird zumal sehr oft der Unterricht ausfällt. In diesen 2 Wochen, in denen die Schüler zu Hause in den Familien fehlen, muss die Schule Personal, Räumlichkeiten und Verpflegung zur Verfügung stellen. Hierdurch entstehen den Schulen Kosten, die aber letztendlich die Familien über die Schulgebühren bezahlen müssen. Auf Anregung Kabalis ( Seine Vorstellung war, dass die Schüler eine Klasse, ihre Noten online abfragen können ) haben wir uns Gedanken gemacht, wie man dem entgegenwirken könnte. Es war Weihnachten 2012 und nach einigen Tagen hatten wir eine konkrete Idee und machten uns an die Lösung des Problems. Noch ahnten wir nicht, wie umfangreich unser Projekt werden würde. Aber, es war die Geburtsstunde von "MyReport".

MyReport - die Software
Nach meiner Rückkehr habe ich mit einem befreundeten Programmierer gesprochen und konnte ihn für unser Projekt gewinnen. Seit Anfang Januar 2013 arbeitet Gerald unentgeldlich an der Entwicklung der benötigten Software. Anfang Mai 2013 hatten wir eine erste Version fertig und ich konnte sie zusammen mit Kabali den ersten Schulen vorstellen. In zwei Monaten besuchten wir über achtzig private Secondary Schools. Die Schulen waren durch die Bank weg interessiert, hatten aber jede Menge zusätzlicher Wünsche und Ideen. Das bedeutete für uns, dass unserer Online-Lösung nicht ausreichend war. Wir haben seitdem unsere Software kontinuierlich weiter entwickelt und ergänzt. Nun gibt es nicht nur einen Online-Service, sondern auch einen Print-Service zum Drucken der Zeugnisse, einen Upload-Service für Prüfungs- und Ferienarbeiten, einen Communication-Service für Lehrer - Eltern / Schüler und einen Website-Service für Schulen die noch keine Homepage haben. Bis Anfang 2014 haben wir nunmehr über 130 Schulen angesprochen. Am 16. November 2013 hatten wir unsere erste große Präsentation vor eingeladenen Vertretern von privaten Sekundarschulen im angemieteten Saal des Kolpinghotel Kampala. Das war für uns eine sehr enttäuschende und frustrierende Geschichte. Von 30 eingeladenen Schulen waren lediglich 10 % erschienen. Wenn denn abgesagt wurde, waren die Grund mehrheitlich, dass die Schule keine Zeit habe, da Prüfungen für S4 und S6 anstanden. Wir haben viel dazu gelernt und reichlich Lehrgeld gezahlt. Aber es geht weiter.

Gründung eines Unternehmens
Damit alles seine Ordnung hat, ließen am 21. Februar 2013, Gladys und ihr Bruder dieses Unternehmen bei den zuständigen Behörden registrieren.


Ziele
Wir wollen: Schulen unterstützen um Kosten zu sparen und Lehrer zu entlasten. Wir wollen die Schulen ermutigen die so freiwerdenden Gelder in die Ausstattung der Schulen zu investieren und Stipendien zu vergeben. Hierdurch können wir zusammen mit den Schulen Kindern in Afrika zu mehr und besseren Unterricht verhelfen.

Durch unser Projekt erreichen wir die folgenden Ziele:
  • Kostensenkung für Schulen und Familien
  • mehr Unterrichtszeit für Schulen
  • Zeitgerechte Ausgabe von einheitlichen Zeugnissen
  • längere Ferien für Schüler
  • Entlastung der Familien

Durch ihre Unterstützung können wir:
  • unsere Software weiter verbessern Präsentationen organisieren um mehrere Schulen auf einmal zu erreichen
  • Einen Programmierer/IT-Techniker vor Ort mit ins Boot holen
  • Einweisungen für Lehrer in die Bedienung der Software durchführen
  • Arbeitsplätze schaffen
- Als nächster Schritt ist geplant in den nächsten Wochen ein kleines Büro zu eröffnen, in dem die anfallenden Arbeiten erledigt und Besucher empfangen werden können.
- Später sollen landesweit kleine Büros eingerichtet werden, wo die Schulen zum Beispiel ihre gedruckten Zeugnisse abholen können.

Dringende Notwendigkeit - ein Büro muß her !
Leider müssen wir schon jetzt ein kleines Büro einrichten. Immer wieder haben die Schulen gefragt, wo denn unser Büro ist. Es wird einfach nicht akzeptiert, dass wir zu Hause arbeiten. Ein Unternehmen muss wohl in Uganda ein Büro haben. Hier zeigt sich, dass Uganda noch ein Entwicklungsland ist. In Deutschland / Europa ist soetwas mittlerweilen selbstverständlich. Dieses war so noch nicht vorgesehen. Wir haben mittlerweile über 4.000 Arbeitsstunden ( umgerechnet über $ 400.000 ) für die Softwareentwicklung, Erstellung von Dokumentationen und Bedienungsanleitungen für die User usw... aufgebracht. Hinzu kamen Kosten für Flüge, Transport, Unterkunft, Verpflegung usw. Soll es das gewesen sein? Wir wollen und werden auf jeden Fall weitermachen. Nach einen großen Kassensturz haben wir die Kosten für das erste Jahr ermittelt. Trotz vieler Einschränkungen und Abstriche, kam da doch noch einiges zusammen.

Laufende Kosten für ein Büro (ca.):  $/Monat
 Miete

200,00
 >Strom  20,00
 wasser

7,00
 
Einmalige Ausstattung für ein Büro (ca.):

$
 Büroausstattung

4500,00
 2 PC / Laptop, 2 Drucker (Farblaser)

2200,00
 Büromaterial

1200,00
 
Personalkosten/Löhne (ca.):

$/Monat
 Bürokraft

300,00
 Fahrer

275,00
 
Transport und Fahrtkosten (ca.): $/Monat
 Fahrzeugmiete

275,00
 Kraftstoff

275,00
 
Werbung (ca.):

$
 Flyers / Vorschlag für Schulen 150,00
 Visitenkarten 100,00
 
4 Präsentationen mit ca. 80-100 Schulertretern

$/Präsentation
 Anmietung Tagungsraum / hall 350,00

 Verpflegung der Gäste

 350,00
Alles zusammen werden sich die Gesamtkosten, wenn wir voll durchstarten wollen, für jedes Jahr auf mindestens ca. $ 25.000 belaufen. Natürlich hoffen wir noch im Laufe des Jahres 2015 die ersten Schulen als Kunden gewinnen zu können. Aber dafür gibt es keine Garantie.
Als einer der nächsten Schritte ist ein Treffen mit dem Ministerium für Ausbildung und Sport geplant. Viele Schulen waren und sind an dieser Softwarelösung sehr interessiert, aber sie scheuen den nächsten bzw. den ersten Schritt zu gehen.
Back to the english version!

All together there will be costs, for the first two years of about $ 50,000. Of course, we hope to win the first schools as customers during the year 2015.
If we receive more support as needed, the funds are fully incorporated into our social engagement.

Our objective economic and social intention
It is planned that the use of My Report will cost the schools in the base version not more than maximum $ 0.50 - 1.00 per student per year. So that we can cover the running costs and still earn some profit.
We will continue our way (see above), therefore we believe in our success, that we will be able in future , to support childrens, pupils & students. That we are able to support families to give their children an education and /or to learn a profession.
Further on we are working on other social projects to help the people in Africa. We also want to enable children from poor families to attend school and support students.
Thank you for reading. We would be very pleased to welcome you as one of our donators.
Siegfried Brandt
Deutsche ProjektbeschreibungMit unserem Projekt geben wir nicht nur Schulen in Uganda die Möglichkeit schnell und einfach Zeugnisse und Bescheinigungen für ihre Schüler und Studenten auszustellen. Die eingesparte Zeit kann effektiver zum Lehren genutzt werden. Die Wartezeiten der Schüler und Studenten ("lausy weeks" genannt) fallen weg. Die tatsächliche Ferienzeit für die Schüler würde sich verlängern. Kosten für Schüler, Studenten und Schulen können reduziert werden.

Vorwort
Ende Januar 2011 lernte ich meine jetzige Verlobte Gladys kennen. Gladys stammt aus Uganda und lebte dort zusammen mit ihrer alleinerziehenden Mutter, einer Tante, ihren fünf Geschwistern und einer Nichte in einem kleinen Haus mit zwei Zimmern. Zu ihren Geschwistern gehört auch ihr Bruder Kabali, welcher zu der Zeit gerade die Highschool mit Erfolg beendet hatte. Nach längerem Brief und Emailkontakt sowie später einigen Telefongesprächen besuchte ich Gladys in Uganda.Mein erster Aufenthalt in Uganda war ein ganz tolles Erlebnis. Zuerst erschütterte mich die große Armut. Das durchschnittliche Jahreseinkommen liegt bei ca. 600 Dollar im Jahr. Danach erkannte ich bald, dass in Uganda vieles im Aufbau ist. Aber bedingt durch die Armut gibt es nur kleine Fortschritte. Besondere Aufmerksamkeit erregte das Schulsystem, da die Geschwister von Gladys alle noch zur Schule gehen. Es unterscheidet sich deutlich vom Deutschen Schulsystem.
Gladys begann nach der Highschool ein Studium an der Makerere Universität of Business in Kampala. Als sich ihre Eltern trennten, schaffte es ihre Mutter nicht die Studiengebühren aufzubringen. Deshalb musste Gladys ihr Studium abbrechen und nahm Mitte 2010 eine Arbeit an. Mit ihrem Einkommen in Höhe von 200,- Dollar/Monat ernährt sie jetzt die Familie, zahlt die Miete und unterstützt die Geschwister bei den Schulgebühren.Gladys, die auch ihren Bruder Kabali unterstützt, ist damit an die Grenze ihrer Möglichkeiten angelangt. Beinahe hätte Kabali nicht seinen Abschluss machen können. Hier konnte ich zum Glück unterstützen und bekam so einen sehr guten Einblick in das bestehende Schulsystem.Das Schulsystem und KostenIn Uganda gibt es eine Schulpflicht bis zur Klasse 7. Ein Schuljahr ist in drei Terms unterteilt und beginnt in Januar. Üblicherweise starten alle Kinder in der Nurseryschool. Dieses ist vergleichbar mit Kindergarten und / oder Vorschule. Es folgt die Primary School, vergleichbar Grund- / Hauptschule, bis zur 7. Klasse. Danach folgt die Secundary School mit sechs weiterführenden Klassen beginnend mit S1. Das "O" Level beendet man mit Abschluß der Klasse S4 ( vergleichbar Mittlere Reife ) und das "A" Level endet mit Abschluß der Klasse S6 ( Abitur ). Damit ist diese schulische Ausbildung beendet.

Mit Abschluß S4 beginnt dann das Arbeitsleben mit Besuch einer "Vocationalschool" vergleichbar mit einer Berufschule, wenn denn die Eltern dieses finanzieren können. Allerdings entspricht das nicht unserem Dualen Ausbildungssystem ! Wer es schafft die Studiengebühren zu bezahlen hat mit erfolgreichem Abschluß des "A" Level die Chance ein Studium zu beginnen. Die übliche Studiendauer beträgt zwei Jahre.

Man sollte aber daran denken, dass nur Kinder deren Eltern über die entsprechende finanziellen Mittel verfügen, der Schulbesuch möglich ist, Dann kann man sogar eine der vielen guten privaten Schulen besuchen.

Die Kosten für die Eltern setzten sich aus Schulgebühren, Unterkunft, Verpflegung, Schulkleidung, Schulmaterialien und Transport zusammen. Sie liegen je nach Schule und Level zwischen ca. 250.000 Ush und über 1.000.000 Ush je Term. Ungerechnet sind das ca. 100 bis über 400 Dollar.

Einige Beispiele: Das Gehalt eines Grundschullehrers beträgt ca. 150.000 Ush. Ein Lehrer einer privaten Secundary School liegt bei ca, 350.000 Ush; Eine gute Bürokraft erhält ca. 700.000 Ush. Ein Liter Benzin kostet ca. 3.250 Ush.Das ProblemAm Ende eines jeden Terms sollten die Schüler ihre Zeiugnisse erhalten. Und hier gibt es ein großes Problem.

Viele Schule, bis auf wenige Ausnahmen eigentlich fast alle, erstellen die Zeugnisse noch von Hand. Bei Klassengrößen von bis zu 100 Schülern ist es somit kein Wunder, dass Lehrer bis zu zwei Wochen brauchen um das zu bewerkstelligen.

Von Kabali habe ich erfahren, dass dieser Zeitraum " lausy weeks " genannt und von den Schülern gehaßt wird zumal sehr oft der Unterricht ausfällt. In diesen 2 Wochen, in denen die Schüler zu Hause in den Familien fehlen, muss die Schule Personal, Räumlichkeiten und Verpflegung zur Verfügung stellen. Hierdurch entstehen den Schulen Kosten, die aber letztendlich die Familien über die Schulgebühren bezahlen müssen.

Auf Anregung Kabalis ( Seine Vorstellung war, dass die Schüler eine Klasse, ihre Noten online abfragen können ) haben wir uns Gedanken gemacht, wie man dem entgegenwirken könnte. Es war Weihnachten 2012 und nach einigen Tagen hatten wir eine konkrete Idee und machten uns an die Lösung des Problems. Noch ahnten wir nicht, wie umfangreich unser Projekt werden würde. Aber, es war die Geburtsstunde von "MyReport".MyReport - die Software
Nach meiner Rückkehr habe ich mit einem befreundeten Programmierer gesprochen und konnte ihn für unser Projekt gewinnen. Seit Anfang Januar 2013 arbeitet Gerald unentgeldlich an der Entwicklung der benötigten Software.

Anfang Mai 2013 hatten wir eine erste Version fertig und ich konnte sie zusammen mit Kabali den ersten Schulen vorstellen. In zwei Monaten besuchten wir über achtzig private Secondary Schools. Die Schulen waren durch die Bank weg interessiert, hatten aber jede Menge zusätzlicher Wünsche und Ideen.

Das bedeutete für uns, dass unserer Online-Lösung nicht ausreichend war.

Wir haben seitdem unsere Software kontinuierlich weiter entwickelt und ergänzt. Nun gibt es nicht nur einen Online-Service, sondern auch einen Print-Service zum Drucken der Zeugnisse, einen Upload-Service für Prüfungs- und Ferienarbeiten, einen Communication-Service für Lehrer - Eltern / Schüler und einen Website-Service für Schulen die noch keine Homepage haben.

Bis Anfang 2014 haben wir nunmehr über 130 Schulen angesprochen. Am 16. November 2013 hatten wir unsere erste große Präsentation vor eingeladenen Vertretern von privaten Sekundarschulen im angemieteten Saal des Kolpinghotel Kampala. Das war für uns eine sehr enttäuschende und frustrierende Geschichte. Von 30 eingeladenen Schulen waren lediglich 10 % erschienen. Wenn denn abgesagt wurde, waren die Grund mehrheitlich, dass die Schule keine Zeit habe, da Prüfungen für S4 und S6 anstanden. Wir haben viel dazu gelernt und reichlich Lehrgeld gezahlt. Aber es geht weiter.

 
Gründung eines Unternehmens
Damit alles seine Ordnung hat, ließen am 21. Februar 2013, Gladys und ihr Bruder dieses Unternehmen bei den zuständigen Behörden registrieren.
Ziele
Wir wollen:

Schulen unterstützen um Kosten zu sparen und Lehrer zu entlasten. Wir wollen die Schulen ermutigen die so freiwerdenden Gelder in die Ausstattung der Schulen zu investieren und Stipendien zu vergeben. Hierdurch können wir zusammen mit den Schulen Kindern in Afrika zu mehr und besseren Unterricht verhelfen.  

 

Durch unser Projekt erreichen wir die folgenden Ziele:

    
Kostensenkung für Schulen und Familien 

mehr Unterrichtszeit für Schulen 

Zeitgerechte Ausgabe von einheitlichen Zeugnissen 

längere Ferien für Schüler
Entlastung der Familien 


Durch ihre Unterstützung können wir:
unsere Software weiter verbessern

Präsentationen organisieren um mehrere Schulen auf einmal zu erreichen 
Einen Programmierer/IT-Techniker vor Ort mit ins Boot holen 

Einweisungen für Lehrer in die Bedienung der Software durchführen 

Arbeitsplätze schaffen 


- Als nächster Schritt ist geplant in den nächsten Wochen ein kleines Büro zu eröffnen, in dem die anfallenden Arbeiten erledigt und Besucher empfangen werden können. 
- Später sollen landesweit kleine Büros eingerichtet werden, wo die Schulen zum Beispiel ihre gedruckten Zeugnisse abholen können.
Dringende Notwendigkeit - ein Büro muß her !Leider müssen wir schon jetzt ein kleines Büro einrichten. Immer wieder haben die Schulen gefragt, wo denn unser Büro ist. Es wird einfach nicht akzeptiert, dass wir zu Hause arbeiten. Ein Unternehmen muss wohl in Uganda ein Büro haben. Hier zeigt sich, dass Uganda noch ein Entwicklungsland ist. In Deutschland / Europa ist soetwas mittlerweilen selbstverständlich.

Dieses war so noch nicht vorgesehen. Wir haben mittlerweile über 4.000 Arbeitsstunden ( umgerechnet über $ 400.000 ) für die Softwareentwicklung, Erstellung von Dokumentationen und Bedienungsanleitungen für die User usw... aufgebracht. Hinzu kamen Kosten für Flüge, Transport, Unterkunft, Verpflegung usw. Soll es das gewesen sein? Wir wollen und werden auf jeden Fall weitermachen.

Nach einen großen Kassensturz haben wir die Kosten für das erste Jahr ermittelt. Trotz vieler Einschränkungen und Abstriche, kam da doch noch einiges zusammen.

Laufende Kosten für ein Büro (ca.):
 $/Monat


 Miete
200,00


 >Strom
 20,00


 wasser
7,00

 

Einmalige Ausstattung für ein Büro (ca.):
$


 Büroausstattung
4500,00


 2 PC / Laptop, 2 Drucker (Farblaser)
2200,00


 Büromaterial
1200,00

 

Personalkosten/Löhne (ca.):
$/Monat


 Bürokraft
300,00


 Fahrer
275,00

 

Transport und Fahrtkosten (ca.):
$/Monat


 Fahrzeugmiete
275,00


 Kraftstoff
275,00

 

Werbung (ca.):
$


 Flyers / Vorschlag für Schulen
150,00


 Visitenkarten
100,00

 

4 Präsentationen mit ca. 80-100 Schulertretern
$/Präsentation


 Anmietung Tagungsraum / hall
350,00


 Verpflegung der Gäste
350,00

 

  	 

Alles zusammen werden sich die Gesamtkosten, wenn wir voll durchstarten wollen, für jedes Jahr auf mindestens ca. $ 25.000 belaufen. Natürlich hoffen wir noch im Laufe des Jahres 2015 die ersten Schulen als Kunden gewinnen zu können. Aber dafür gibt es keine Garantie.

Als einer der nächsten Schritte ist ein Treffen mit dem Ministerium für Ausbildung und Sport geplant. Viele Schulen waren und sind an dieser Softwarelösung sehr interessiert, aber sie scheuen den nächsten bzw. den ersten Schritt zu gehen.



Back to the english version!

story:
Hey guys, Tricia here! I wanted to give you some background on why Great Strides is so important to me. When I was growing up, I had a very tough time. I was born with Cystic Fibrosis, an inherited life-threatening disorder that damages the lungs and digestive system. I've always been fortunate enough to be one of the "healthier" CF patients in the world, but CF caused many different strains on my life. I was bullied for being "different", for being way too skinny(at the time), for coughing all the time; I had many people tell me that I was going to die when I get older as a form of harassment. My brother Stephen, who is three years younger than me, also has CF and went through a very similar experience.

Stephen and I are both huge nerds; we have been since they would put us to sleep with Star Wars wearing our hand-me-down Batman onesie from our older sister, Katie; to now as adults who make cosplays(costume play) and run around at conventions, photo shoots, movie premiers, etc.; so what better way to join two of the most important things in our lives than by having a Cosplay Barbeque to benefit Great Strides?

Great Strides is a walk in that supports the members of the community, from the patients to the loved ones, by bringing people together to raise money for the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. The FDA and American Government does not actively research cures for CF, since only 30,000 people are diagnosed the the US, so funding for research falls onto the members of the community. The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, or CFF, raises the funds and awareness to get breakthrough medicines, like Kalydeco, researched and developed, and manufactured into the community.

With funds being raised almost entirely by the patients and loved ones with CF, the magnitude your contributions has on this is huge; your donation can push us one step closer to a cure in Stephen's and my life time!

I want to raise at most $600 for the foundation from this event. I plan on having different perks and gifts for each type of donation. My goal is to throw an awesome

For $10, you can enjoy delicious barbeque food and fun times with your friends! Perfect for the non-cosplaying nerds who just like to people watch.

For $30, you'll get the barbeque perk, with a 20 minute long photo shoot with one of our photographers, Mr. Snow  and Tsuki CosPhotography!

For $50, you'll get the barbeque, the photo shoot, AND an exclusive T-Shirt designed by Filthy Warumono for the event!

story:
What Is BLISS?

BLISS exists for one reason - to provide adolescent girls an education while simultaneously lifting them out of poverty through high-fashion.

It enables school attendance for girls who would otherwise be driven by poverty to work full-time instead. 

Before BLISS, enrolled girls spent 14 hours every day working at carpet looms. Now, they come to school, learn English, Urdu, and Math as well as embroidery in a 1-hour skills class. The embroidered fabric is finished into trendy handbags for sale in global markets. The money goes back to the girls so they can support their families while getting an education - win-win!


You can view the complete collection of handbags here. AND when you contribute, you can claim your choice of an exquisite handbag from the collection; view perks to find out how!






How We Know It Works

  • BLISS is bringing 30 girls to school in Pakistan, giving them education & practical skills
  • Girls' hourly income has increased by 60% through BLISS, compared to when working full-time
  • Attendance rates are now at 90%, higher than ever at these schools
  • Our first line of handbags sold out within weeks; we are now struggling to meet demand!

BLISS has also instilled a sense of dignity, pride and self-confidence in the girls. School is now perceived as more fun, relevant and practical.

"BLISS has reduced the burden of education on my father. I love coming to school to study and embroider with other girls!" - Fatima, 14 years old.


How We Can Grow With Your Help

BLISS sold out its first line of handbags in June 2011 in Pakistan. Dozens more girls want to join and are wait-listed for enrollment.


We don't have enough bags to meet the demand; and we don't have the funds to enroll more girls to scale operations!


With the funds from the campaign here, plus matching grants we are raising from investors, we aim to:


  • Scale from the current 30 to 120 girls in 2012
  • Launch our products in 6 cities - London, Paris, New York, Seattle, Boulder & Nairobi - through a network of female ambassadors, between Feb & Apr 2012 
  • Launch a financial literacy curriculum for the girls in December 2011
  • Design and launch a brand new logo & website, to spread our mission and products globally


The more handbags produced and sold, the more students BLISS can educate and train - it's a virtuous cycle. $300 keeps 1 girl in school for 1 year!


A BLISSful Vision


BLISS' vision is that of no girl left behind, of every young girl able to define the course of her own life. There is no simple or obvious future for millions of young girls without BLISS - a culturally acceptable solution to a highly intractable problem.








We invite each and every one of you to be part of our BLISS!


Have questions or feedback, or just want to say hello? team@bagsforbliss.org would love to hear from you!

We are so excited for all the thousands of lives we will change through this work in my second home, Indonesia.

Joelle Croteau-Willard

story:
See the full story here: http://www.wusa9.com/news/article/209834/158/Marine-veteran-Donald-Stutsman-of-McLean-Va-thwarted-by-failure-of-College-Handling-of-GI-Bill

Virginia Marine veteran Donald Stutsman who fought in Iraq is stuck in limbo after what he considers a failure of the GI Bill.  A breakdown in the system has put his life on hold and left him with mounting college debt.

Stutsman, 30, would rather be in college today than tinker with his jeep.  But Northern Virginia Community College won't re-admit him, or give him his transcripts until he pays a $2,719.50 bill for the last semester.  He enrolled under the GI Bill and says he was told his tuition was all covered.

"He said don't worry, you're 100 percent covered," Stutsman says he was told by counselors at NOVA.

But he wasn't covered--an August 2011 change to the GI Bill meant that the VA would pay the in-state tuition for NOVA and Mr. Stutsman would have to cover the rest.

Mr. Stutsman is on the wrong end of a raw deal--so let's lend a helping hand to a fellow veteran.

This project seeks to raise the $2719.50 needed to pay the balance of his tuition (the project is designed to raise $3000 to cover Indiegogo and Paypal fees). Your reward? Knowing you did the right thing.

*I have no connection to Mr. Stutsman other than being a fellow veteran who is interested in helping him past this hurdle. I am presently working to get in contact with him and Ms. Fox (the journalist who wrote the story) to ensure the money gets to the right place.

story:
Summary

Friends of Tara is a group of friends dedicated to celebrating the life and memory of Tara McCartney. Each year, we launch a campaign to capture the spirit of this remarkable woman. Tara was extremely kind and thoughtful. She had a knack of providing just what was needed to those around her – a dear note, beautiful handcrafted piece of jewelry or just the perfect trinket. As a point of inspiration, we decided to leverage this spirit of thoughtfulness to spotlight two worthy entities – Vista Maria and the Tara Partrice McCartney (nee Ervin) Scholarship Fund. By contributing to this campaign, Friends of Tara will put basic necessities into hands of young girls in Vista Maria’s Community Program and provide financing to a scholarship fund that provides $1,000 each year to two students.

What We Need & What You Get

The goal of this campaign is to raise $1,000 to help support the scholarship and provide at least 30 hygiene kits, water bottles, or pairs of gloves to Vista Maria. Any monetary proceeds from this campaign will go directly to the scholarship fund. This is our way of keeping Tara in our hearts as well as spreading a little bit of her joy and love to others.

We selected Sweetest Day as the ideal time to kick this campaign off. In the spirit of giving, we have established several unique perks for the kindness shown by the campaign's contributors:

$9: Hydration Salvation (3 btls) = These three colorful water bottles will help ensure that young girls have a way to stay hydrated throughout the day. We will send you a special thank you for your generosity! Note: The water bottles will be purchased on your behalf and delivered directly to Vista Maria.


$15: Glove Love (3 pairs) = These three pairs of fuzzy gloves will make sure that girls' fingers stay toasty through the winter months. We will send you a special thank you for your generosity! Note: The gloves will be purchased on your behalf and delivered directly to Vista Maria.


$12: A Hygiene Kit (1) = Sometimes the sweetest things are the things we take for granted. This special custom hygiene kit will come with soap, shampoo, deodorant and a special gift for the young girl. The materials will come in reusable polka dot plastic container with lid making it the perfect little package. We will send you a special thank you for your generosity! Note: The kit will be purchased on your behalf and delivered directly to Vista Maria.


$15: Set of Earrings (1) = These pretty little sparklers will bring a little pizzazz to your season.  The brilliance of this set will only heighten your loveliness.


$18: Beautiful Bangle (1) = This beautiful bangle is custom made and very on trend. The gold colored wire-wrapped bangle showcases luxurious clear stones. It’s sure to get you noticed and will be mailed directly to you!


$20: Garden Charm (1) = Tara loved the beauty of the outdoors and a pretty garden.  This handmade garden marker is heat and cold resistant made of clay and brass. To commemorate one of Tara’s most precious things, the charm will be engraved with the word “Friendship” to garner your garden.


$20: Trio of Care (1) = Truly make an impact in a young girl’s life by providing a trio of care in the form of a water bottle, warm gloves, and a hygiene kit.  Go above and beyond by selecting this perk. We will send you a special thank you for your generosity! Note: The trio of care items will be purchased on your behalf and delivered directly to Vista Maria.


$35: 1 Ticket - The Sweetest Things Tea = Celebrate this holiday in a unique way! For your donation, receive a ticket to a special Holiday Tea being held at the Sweet Afton Tea Room in Plymouth, Michigan on Saturday, December 20 from 9:00am - 11:00am. The Sweet Afton Tea Room is at 450 Forest Avenue, Plymouth, Michigan 48170. Check out their website at http://www.sweetaftontearoom.com/.


$65: 2 Tickets -The Sweetest Things Tea = What better way to celebrate then to share tea with a friend? Plus, you will be surrounded by beautiful holiday décor while enjoying some fantastic food. For your donation, receive two tickets to a special Holiday Tea being held at the Sweet Afton Tea Room in Plymouth, Michigan on Saturday, December 20 from 9:00am - 11:00am. The Sweet Afton Tea Room is at 450 Forest Avenue, Plymouth, Michigan 48170. Check out their website at http://www.sweetaftontearoom.com/.


$130: 4 Tickets -The Sweetest Things Tea = Are you eager to have a special holiday celebration you’re your best friends? Purchase these tickets – this event will not disappoint! For your donation, receive four tickets to a special Holiday Tea being held at the Sweet Afton Tea Room in Plymouth, Michigan on Saturday, December 20 from 9:00am - 11:00am. The Sweet Afton Tea Room is at 450 Forest Avenue, Plymouth, Michigan 48170. Check out their website at http://www.sweetaftontearoom.com/.


 $180: 6 Tickets (1 Table) - The Sweetest Things Tea = Gather a group of friends and celebrate the holidays over tea by having your own table at the tea! This is such a great deal – you save $30 by committing to table. For your donation, receive a reserved table for 6 at a special Holiday Tea being held at the Sweet Afton Tea Room in Plymouth, Michigan on Saturday, December 20 from 9:00am - 11:00am. The Sweet Afton Tea Room is at 450 Forest Avenue, Plymouth, Michigan 48170. Check out their website at http://www.sweetaftontearoom.com/.


The Impact

The $1,000 goal will fund one student a $1,000 scholarship for a year. Students receiving the scholarship are selected with preference going to female students who are English majors, and are strong academics (Overall GPA: 3.2+). Imagine the ability to assist a student pay for class credits, buy textbooks or help with housing costs.  Additionally, purchasing one of the four offered Vista Maria perks will allow you to make a small, meaningful difference in a young girl’s life. Tara made this world a better, brighter place—and now you can do the same!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to make a contribution, there are still ways that you can help. Please get the word out to everyone that you know about the campaign. Notify your social networks using the Indiegogo share tools. Help us make sure that Tara's memory and spirit lives on.

Friendship & Best Wishes!

Friends of Tara

P.S. For more information about Vista Maria, please visit https://www.vistamaria.org/.

Friends of Tara is a group of friends dedicated to celebrating
the life and memory of Tara McCartney. Each year, we launch a campaign to
capture the spirit of this remarkable woman. Tara was extremely kind and
thoughtful. She had a knack of providing just what was needed to those around
her – a dear note, beautiful handcrafted piece of jewelry or just the perfect
trinket. As a point of inspiration, we decided to leverage this spirit of thoughtfulness
to spotlight two worthy entities – Vista
Maria and the Tara Partrice
McCartney (nee Ervin) Scholarship Fund. By contributing to this campaign, Friends
of Tara will put basic necessities into hands of young girls in
Vista Maria’s Community Program and provide financing to a scholarship fund
that provides $1,000 each year to two students. 
What We Need & What You
Get
The goal of this campaign is to raise $1,000 to help support the
scholarship and provide at least 30 hygiene kits, water bottles, or pairs of gloves to Vista Maria. Any monetary proceeds from this campaign
will go directly to the scholarship fund. This is our way of keeping Tara in
our hearts as well as spreading a little bit of her joy and love to others.
We selected Sweetest Day as the ideal time to kick this campaign off. In the spirit of giving, we
have established several unique perks for the kindness shown by the campaign's

story:
What…what? A music-thon? What is that?!!!

WE are having our 1st official 24 hour Music-thon to support our instrumental students and their dream of going to Europe. We are going to have non-stop music for a full 24 hours starting at 6 p.m. on October 31st (yes, Halloween!!!) and wrapping up at 6 p.m. on November 1st. There are 38 slots, 9 one hour slots and 29 half hour slots for each student to perform. There will be soloists and ensembles that will continue throughout the night with lots of coffee, sugar and adrenaline. All we need is your support :)

Why is this important…

We hear the term worldy which denotes traveling to a foreign country. There are amazing musicians within this program that have never even travelled outside of our metropolitan area. Going into the "city" to Governor's School is the the best thing that has happened to them!
Imagine the ripple effect you can create when sponsoring the efforts of these musicians. These students not only visit Europe, but have the opportunity to play in Innsbrook and Salzburg for all to hear. The ripple is larger than you can imagine! Helping them become "WORLDY"  also inspires each of them to follow their dreams of music outside of Norfolk, Virginia. This might be the trip that defines who they "can" and will be in the future.

What do we need?

As much as you can donate! We set a low goal with hopes of blowing this out of the park (or orchestral studio!) The funds will offset the 31 students attending. With the costs being over $3000.00 per student we need a LOT of HELP.

    If we don't have the support...

    There are some students that would LOVE to go on this trip, but do not have the means to attend. Will you help? Your small donation can change a person's life…forever.

    Other ways you can help :)

    If you don't have the funds to sponsor please shout this out to your friends and to their friends (and parents!!!) It just takes one drop to change the wave. Let's do this and make our 1st Music-thon an off the chart event!

story:
What is this all about?

Lena and Clare have just completed our first year of the Master of Teaching at University of Melbourne. 

Chalkboard Kenya approached University of Melbourne teacher candidates to volunteer on their project that sees the children of Mama Children's Orphanage in Busia, Kenya receive tuition from aspiring young teachers for 5 weeks at a time over projects that span a year.

We jumped at the opportunity to be a part of a project that gives back to some of the most inspiring children in the world. 

We are also excited at the prospect of teaching engaging but thoughtful lessons and to learn a little something about the world while we do what we love.

But most importantly, every child has a human right to an education, why should these children miss out?

What We Need & What You Get

So to get ourselves over to Busia we need flights, visas and vaccinations. Combined thats how much we are asking through this project.

All money raised goes entirely into getting us to the orphanage which includes flights, visas and vaccinations. Part of the money will go to the orphanage to pay for the food and accommodation we will need whilst we are there.

The balance we have already paid with our savings.

We have super exciting perks for different levels of pledges, ranging from receiving a small gift we collect for you during our time in Kenya, photos and prints from the National Park around the orphanage, tuition for you or your children, a limited edition print from a local artist and of course every pledge comes with a big virtual hug from us.

Your Impact

By pledging even the smallest amount to our campaign you are helping a child to gain when they have already lost so much.

Whilst we are over there we will keep a regular blog for you to share the experience with us and see how your dollars are helping educate the children at the orphanage.

The Tiny Risk

A lot of sad things are happening around the world and particularly in the continent of Africa. But with that said Kenya is a stable country which is ebola-free and politically stable as it gets in this current climate. 

The orphanage is a secure place (as it should be, being the home of so many children) and we will be in a safe environment during our time there. 

With that said, not everything runs to plan, and if in the 0.0001% chance we don't get over there for reasons beyond our means, we will put all dollars raised from this campaign into us teaching in another orphanage somewhere in the world. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know not everyone can contribute but there are other ways to help - mainly make some noise about our campaign amongst your family and friends!

story:
We are a group of four students from The Portsmouth Grammar School. As part of the Faith and Football Social Enterprise Charity Challenge we are aiming to publish books under the company name of ‘By The Community’.

We have the idea of asking the Portsmouth Community,particularly our school teachers and fellow students;

What are your favourite aide memoirs?

​​​​What are your favourite fast and easy recipes?

What are your favourite jokes?

 

With the input from our school community and anyone else in the local area who wishes to contribute we are going to printbooks, based on the above questions. All book sales will go to the Portsmouth Based charity “Faith and Football” Linvoy Primus, ex-Portsmouth footballer, is one of the patrons of the charity.

 

We would love to make our idea possible but we really need funding to print the books. We hoped that the community (you) will be able to sponsor us with a small donation.


Our main sales day will be the Faith and Football trading day in Cascades on the 21st March.
We really hope you can help us and support our local charity challenge.

story:
Our amazing friend and a dedicated trans activist, Dirk, recently decided that he wants to dedicate an even larger portion of his life to helping vulnerable trans people. He wants to become a trans youth counsellor. 


Trans people are disproportionately likely to suffer from bad mental health as a result of having to live in a transphobic society. In fact, as many as 41% of us end up trying to take our life because we don't feel like we can cope with the obstacles in our way. Currently, it is extremely difficult to get any psychological help in the UK. Things are even worse if you are trans. Often, the very people who are meant to help  us end up making things worse. Therapists will unconsciously, or sometimes consciously, say things that put the blame on us, as if it is us who are faulty, not the society. We need more trans counsellors who will help us deal with our traumas while creating an environemnt that sees us as normal. We need more amazing people like Dirk, who will guide young trans people into creating lives for themselves, who will help us figure out how to engage with and find a place within the wider society, and who will give us support at times when we have none.

To make this happen, Dirk needs to complete counselling courses at the City College in Brighton. These will allow him to apply for counselling degree. The two courses that he needs to complete will cost £800 in total (that's not counting the cost of the degree). Any monetary help would be much appreciated as there is currently no way that Dirk would be able to self-fund his education.

story:
Who are we?

The Honduras Project is a group of students from the American School of Tegucigalpa, focused on helping and learning about how to help in our community. Honduras is the most dangerous country in the world and the second poorest country in the Western Hemisphere. If anyone has the power to change this, it is the youth of today, because we are the future of tomorrow. We partner with different organizations and services that operate in Honduras. We want to build long lasting relationships between the AST community and these charities, in hope that we can positively change our future, and the lives of those around us. Although we are students, if we start helping today, we know that we can change tomorrow!

 

What We Need 

We need funds so that we can get started. Any amount of money is useful to our cause, and you will be able to see the impact. All of the money goes directly towards the projects we are working on. Currently, we are trying to raise the funds to:

  • Facilitate the surgery for a little girl with two clubbed feet.
  • Purchase the anti-parasitic and multi-vitamins for the students of an elementary school.
  • Annually provide materials and uniforms for an impoverished nursery.
  • Buy materials for our service projects.
  • Raise awareness for our cause.

 

The Impact

Your donations will allow us to start achieving our goals. We want to provide help and change in our community, while building long-lasting relationships between the youth of Honduras and people/organizations in need.  For example, the money that we have previously raised has gone directly towards supplying the students of one poor rural school with school supplies. If we had more funds, we could do this more often and on a larger scale.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Besides donations you can help by spreading the word! Share our cause on Facebook, Twitter, and Tumblr. The more people who know about the cause, the more funds we can raiser, and the more good we can do in Honduras!

story:
My name is Karl Denny and I will be running the Toronto Marathon on October 20th, 2013.  I have a background working with students and children who have special needs.  This october, I am running the race to raise money for the Tourette Syndrome association of Ontario. It's important for me to raise money for this cause because I believe this is an organization that could use additional funding and donations. By helping donate, not only would I personally appreciate it, you would be helping an organization that provides services for youth and adults with Tourettes Syndrome. 

 Information about the TSAO can be found on their website: http://www.tourettesyndromeontario.ca 

I am looking to raise 840$ for this event, 20$ per KM of the race.  I am sponsoring the first and last kilometer (40$), leaving the remaining 800.  I am looking for individuals who wish to sponsor one KM of the race that I will be running.  If I do not raise the entire amount, I will still be donating whatever I have raised to TSAO.  Of course, if you wish to donate more or less than 20$, I will gladly accept it as well.  I will be wearing green for the marathon. 

Thanks in advance!

Karl Denny

story:
Cette campagne est terminée, mais une nouvelle est en cours 


Notre nouvel objectif est d'améliorer le site web et de financer des bourses pour permettre aux étudiants méritants de passer gratuitement l'examen surveillé.

______________________________________________

Présentation du projet


Le MOOC Gestion de projet est le premier MOOC certificatif créé en France : 45.000 inscriptions ont été enregistrées sur nos 4 éditions.

Notre objectif ? Donner à tous l’accès à une formation de qualité : Management des projets, démarches de gestion des risques, créativité , évaluation d’impact... douze thématiques sont disponibles.


En plus des deux sessions annuelles du MOOC, les formations restent en accès libre en permanence. Ainsi, les statistiques de nos vidéos montrent que sur les 365 derniers jours, plus de 120.000 heures de cours ont été suivies.


Nous voulons maintenant, grâce à votre aide développer et partager une version anglaise des cours !


À quoi servira la collecte ?

D'abord à faire traduire des cours par une traductrice professionnelle, ce qui permettra de vous les proposer en anglais et d'élargir leur accès.


Nous avons un cofinancement de 5.000 € de la Fondation Centrale Initiatives, mais il nous manque 3.000 € pour démarrer le projet.


Si nous collectons plus de 3.000 €, voici ce que nous ferons :

• traduire et enregistrer plus de cours que ceux des premières semaines du MOOC (pour un coût de 7.000 € environ)

• mettre en place un site web en anglais pour y partager les cours : projectmanagementcourse.pm (pour un coût de 2.000 € environ)

• ... mais aussi : améliorer le site actuel gestiondeprojet.pm, utiliser les données du MOOC GdP pour la Recherche, améliorer les plateformes de MOOC existantes en développant de nouvelles fonctions.

Merci de votre contribution !
story_txt:
Cette campagne est terminée, mais une nouvelle est en cours Notre nouvel objectif est d'améliorer le site web et de financer des bourses pour permettre aux étudiants méritants de passer gratuitement l'examen surveillé.

story:
Casa Hogar Hijos de la Luna

is a non-profit organization that helps children in situations of high risk, providing them a safe haven, basic education, clothes, materials; psychological, medical and dental care, recreation and, most importantly, a place that gives each child individualized attention with the love and affection it needs.

For more information please take a look at our website www.hijosdelaluna.org or our Facebook account Casa Hogar Hijos de la Luna de Oaxaca, A.C. 


What We Need & What You Get

Besides basic care we like to offer the children a varied program of culture, education and recreation. In September we would like to take 30 of the children of Casa Hogar Hijos de la Luna on a field trip to Mexico City and Puebla. We already have arranged the accomodation and the entrance fees to Africam Safari, a zoo near Puebla. To make this field trip possible we still need transportation and food.

- Transportation
We would like to rent a bus to take the children from Oaxaca to Mexico City, from there to the highlands of Puebla and back to Oaxaca. The price of the rent of the bus is approximately $5000 MXN pesos a day.

- Food
We calculate that we need approximately $8000 MXN pesos to aliment 30 children and 6 adults during the field trip.

If we reach our goal we will provide our donors with a detailed report of the field trip with photos.

    Itinerary Field trip
    - Friday September 5th
    At night we will drive to Mexico City, arriving there on Saturday morning
    - Saturday September 6th
    Explore Mexico City and visit one of the national museums. At night we will drive to the highlands of Puebla where we will spend the night
    - Sunday September 7th
    Hike in the highlands of Puebla
    - Monday September 8th
    Visit Africam Safari (zoo) and drive back to Oaxaca.

    Impact

    The 30 children of Casa Hogar Hijos de la Luna will have the chance to experience seeing Mexico city and Puebla first hand, enjoying nature and learn about mexican culture and history.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Our organization is supported by volunteers. If you are interested in volunteering, please contact us via email at contacto@hijosdelaluna.org  or give us a call at (951) 132-1687

    For donations in kind such as food, educational materials, paper, equipment, clothes, books, school supplies, and so on please contact us so that we can inform you of what are our present needs are. Thank you very much!

story:
Short Summary

Our children will be the first generation in history to live a shorter life than their parents! By the age of 11, one third of our children are already overweight or obese. It’s time for change and more focused help for children.

We have developed the Kool Kidz programme for primary schools to tackle childhood obesity, involving the three most important people in a child’s formative years – the parents, the teachers and the child.

We use a combination of fun ways to learn about nutrition, taking part in activity without it feeling like hard work, recognising and changing behavioural habits and using cool stuff like social media, texting and our own Youtube channel to deliver the programme.

What We Need & What You Get

It’s all ready to go: we’ve got our expert team ready to get started in the Summer term. But we need your help to fund the first trials in two primary schools. We’ve found two Head Teachers willing to pilot the Kool Kidz programme and we need to cover their costs and time away from their other duties during the trial. If we raise £5,000 we can do one trial. £10,000 will support both trials and any contributions above that will support the roll-out into other schools across the country.

With your help, we can turn the situation around in one generation. Be a part of that change. Pledge a contribution now and, apart from the perks, you’ll receive a much greater reward: the knowledge that you were part of the generation that said ‘No’ to childhood obesity once and for all.

The Impact

Our programme has scale and the potential for national reach. Here’s how we plan to increase the impact of campaign:

March to June: Raise funds and run a 12 week trial programme in two schools

May to July: Make local authorities aware of Kool Kidz

Sept term: Launch Kool Kidz in selected schools across the UK

Jan 2014: Roll out the programme nationally to local authorities, schools and parents

Other Ways You Can Help

Please get in touch with us if your local school or authority is interested to learn more about Kool Kidz.

Our Website : www.foodadvisors.eu

Email: koolkidz@foodadvisors.co.uk

Call: 020 8948 1248 

Meet The Team

Graham Rowan is Chairman of the Obesity Management Association and Chief Executive of Food Advisors. He’s a man on a mission – to stamp out obesity in the UK.  He’s often on TV, radio, newspapers and conferences talking about how we need to make drastic changes to overcome the obesity epidemic that’s threatening to swamp the NHS.

Cheryl Wilson is one of the country’s leading nutritional therapists and one of the very few Harley Street nutritionists to focus on children in her practice. She’s the brains behind the Food Advisors database and is heavily involved in delivering the nutrition elements of the Kool Kidz programme.

Dr Anthony James BA, MEdPsych, DEdPsy is a leading child psychologist who wrote the definitive guide for teachers in how to recognize and deal with stress in school kids. We’re delighted that he has agreed to join the Food Advisors team as a consultant on the behavioural aspects of the Kool Kidz programme.

Cyber Coach has perfected the art of making activity fun for primary school kids. Using their unique games based approach they have taken the stigma of ‘exercise’ away from getting our kids moving again. It’s all about making activity fun rather than work. And when you look at how these kids are enjoying themselves with this unique equipment you can see why it’s been so successful at more than 1,000 schools. You can see more at http://www.cyber-coach.co.uk/
