story:
Español: Hola, por favor ve abajo para leer mi historia y proposito en espanol. 

I'm happy to announce that thanks to your requests, I'm launching a Part II fundraiser.  In our orginal fundraiser, we raised over $3,230!  Let's see if we can raise $570 for Part II to total $3,800! 

----

My name is Freddie and I know that together you and I will make an incredible impact on children’s education.  With your commitment to help me raise the funds, I promise to create and run the first ever San Rafael-Huejucar Marathon (26.2 miles) individually.  All the funds will go to helping a special small rural elementary school. The funds will go a long way, from getting computers to buying much needed teaching materials, to repairing and fixing the school itself. 

Who I am & Why it is Important

Let me tell you about my purpose and why I am passionate about this cause. For the first 10 years of my life I grew up in the small rural town of San Rafael, Mexico, under very humble circumstances.  I attended Escuadron 201 Elementary School, the only school in our town, where I learned to read, write, and do math.  It was also there where I first fell in love with learning. I remember being 8 years old and already dreaming about going to college one day. But at 8 years old, I also knew that my dream would only remain a dream given my family and the town’s rather underprivileged circumstances.  As a kid living in such circumstances, the idea of going to college seemed unattainable. Interestingly enough, life gave me the incredible and unexpected opportunity to go after my dream and I can now tell you that I obtained my bachelor’s and master’s degrees from the University of California-Irvine and Pepperdine University, respectively.

Escuadron 201 built my educational base and planted my dream to achieve higher education. Now it’s my turn to give back!  

Children and Community

San Rafael, located in the highlands of the state of Jalisco and the municipality of Huejucar, is a small agricultural town of a little over 110 people where people raise cattle and grow corn, beans, squash, etc.  San Rafael counts with only one school, Escuadron 201 Elementary School.  Currently, fewer than 20 energetic and diligent kids attend elementary school there.  And, while they are eager to learn, they are in need of many things to have the best education they could have. 

Your Impact

Absolutely all the funds raised will go towards improving the education of the children of Escuadron 201 Elementary School in San Rafael, Huejucar, Mexico. 

Escuadron 201 is in much need of funds for teaching materials and for infrastructure upgrades. The funds will be used for the following purposes:

  • Buy 2 computers so that children learn basic computer skills.
  • Repair the walls of the schools that are in very poor condition. Then,
  • Repaint the entire school.
  • Buy much needed teaching materials on each subject (ex. microscopes, compasses, books, computer programs).
  • Buy basic classroom supplies (ex. pencils, crayons, notebooks, sharpeners, glue, etc.)

The Charity

The funds will be presented as part of the Arcelia Education Foundation, a foundation I’m in the process of establishing in honor my amazing mother who sacrificed a lot to have me achieve a good education. The purpose of this foundation is to help children in underprivileged and socio-economically disadvantaged circumstances to get a solid education.

The Marathon

I will be running what will be in essence the first ever San Rafael-Huejucar Marathon.  While and undergraduate student, I ran my first ever marathon to raise funds for a local charity and since then I’ve done six marathons. For years now, I’ve dreamt of returning to San Rafael and running a marathon there while raising funds for the children of Escuadron 201. The time is now.

Given that San Rafael is halfway between the towns of Huejucar and Monte Escobedo and, surprisingly, the distance between these two towns is a little over a marathon long (26.2 miles), I’ll be running that distance on my own! While marathons are generally difficult, the fact that I’ll be reaching 7,278 above sea level, I know it will be a difficult task. However, I know that with your encouragement and with the fact that this is an important cause for me personally, I will be successful.  

Other Ways You Can Help...

Your donations are key but you can also help by spreading the word. Please share with your friends, family members, co-workers, organizations, etc. via email, Facebook, LinkedIn, Twitter, and Instagram, etc.

Thank you so much for your help.  Please donate as generously as you can.  Together we will have direct impact on the lives and futures of these children and their community.

 

Corro un maratón para la educación infantil de una escuela muy especial en México

Hola a todos! Mi nombre es Freddie y sé que juntos haremos un increíble impacto en la educación infantil. Con tu compromiso de ayudarme a recaudar más de 2.000 dólares EE.UU., yo me comprometo a crear y ejecutar el primer maratón (42.2 km) de San Rafael-Huejucar. Todos los fondos se destinarán a ayudar a una pequeña escuela primaria rural muy especial para mi. Los fondos contribuirán en gran medida para conseguir computadoras, para comprar material de enseñanza muy necesario, y para reparar la infrastructura de la propia escuela.

Quién soy y por qué es importante

Permítanme contarles acerca de mi propósito y por qué estoy muy apasionado por esta causa. Durante los primeros 10 años de mi vida, me crié en el pequeño pueblo rural de San Rafael, en México, en circunstancias muy humildes. Asistí a la Escuela Primaria Escuadrón 201, la única escuela en nuestro rancho/pueblo donde aprendí a leer, escribir y hacer matemática. Fue allí donde por primera vez me enamore del aprendizaje. Recuerdo que a los 8 años yo ya soñaba con ir a la universidad algún día. Sin embargo, a los 8 años de edad, también sabía que mi sueño seguiria siendo solo un sueño dado a las circunstancias bastante desfavorecidas de mi familia y de mi comunidad. Cuando era niño vivía en tales circunstancias que la idea de ir a la universidad parecía inalcanzable. Sorprendentemente, la vida me dio una oportunidad increíble e inesperada de perseguir mi sueño y ahora puedo contarles que obtuve mi licenciatura y maestría de la Universidad de California-Irvine y la Universidad de Pepperdine, respectivamente.

Escuadron 201 construyó mi base educativa y plantó mi sueño de alcanzar la educación superior. Ahora es mi turno de ayudar a las escuela y a los niños que ahora estan pasando por circunstancias similares a las que yo pasé!

Los niños y la comunidad

Mi pequeño San Rafael esta ubicado en la sierra del estado de Jalisco, en el municipio de Huejucar, Jalisco.  Es una pequeña población agrícola de poco más de 110 personas donde se cría ganado y se cultiva maíz, frijol, calabaza, etc. En San Rafael, se cuenta con una sola escuela, Escuela Primaria Escuadrón 201. En la actualidad, menos de 25 niños energéticos y diligentes asisten a la escuela primaria allí. Y, mientras ellos están ansiosos por aprender, están en necesidad de muchas cosas para tener la mejor educación posible.

Tu Impacto

Absolutamente todos los fondos recaudados serán destinados a mejorar la educación de los niños de la Escuela Primaria Escuadrón 201 en San Rafael, Huejucar, Jalisco, México.

Escuadron 201 tiene la gran necesidad de fondos para los materiales de enseñanza y para mejorar la infraestructura. Los fondos se utilizaran para los fines siguientes:

  • Comprar 2 computadoras para que los niños aprenden habilidades básicas de computación.
  • Reparación de las paredes de la escuela que están en muy malas condiciones.
  • Pintar toda la escuela.
  • Comprar materiales de enseñanza para cada materia (ej. microscopios, brújulas, libros, programas informáticos, etc.).
  • Comprar materiales básicos (ej. lápices, crayones, cuadernos, sacapuntas, pegamento, etc.)

La  fundación

Los fondos se presentaran como parte de la Fundación de Educación Arcelia, una fundación que estoy en el proceso de establecer en honor a mi increible madre que sacrificó mucho para yo pudiera conseguir una buena educación. El objetivo de esta fundación es de ayudar a los niños en situaciones desfavorecidas y socio-económicamente en desventaja para obtener una educación sólida.

El maratón de San Rafael-Huejucar

Este maratón es único ya que nunca se ha corrido la ruta anteriormente. Cuando yo era estudiante de licenciatura , corrí mi primer maratón para recaudar fondos para una fundación local y desde entonces he hecho seis maratones en total. Desde hace años, he soñado con regresar a San Rafael y correr un maratón allí con el propósito de recaudar fondos para los niños de Escuadrón 201. El momento es ahora. 

Teniendo en cuenta que San Rafael está a medio camino entre las localidades de Monte Escobedo y Huejucar, y sorprendentemente, la distancia entre estas dos ciudades es un poco más de un maratón de largo (42.2 km), correré esa ruta. Los  maratones son generalmente difíciles, pero el hecho de que voy a correr a mas de 2,500 metros sobre el nivel del mar, sé que va a ser una tarea muy difícil. Sin embargo, sé que con tu apoyo y con el hecho de que esta es una causa muy importante para mí, se que voy a tener éxito…  aunque acabare muy adolorido!

Otras maneras que puedes ayudar

Tus donaciones son fundamentales, pero también puedes ayudar a correr la voz. Por favor, comparte con tus amigos, familiares, compañeros de trabajo, organizaciones, etc. a través de correo electrónico, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn, etc.

Muchas gracias por tu ayuda. Por favor, dona tan generosamente que te sea posible. Juntos vamos a tener un impacto directo en las vidas y el futuro de estos niños y su comunidad.

Absolutamente todos los fondos recaudados serán destinados a mejorar la educación de los niños de la Escuela Primaria Escuadrón 201 en San Rafael, Huejucar, Jalisco, México.
Escuadron 201 tiene la gran necesidad de fondos para los materiales de enseñanza y para mejorar la infraestructura. Los fondos se utilizaran para los fines siguientes:

Comprar 2 computadoras para que los niños aprenden habilidades básicas de computación.
Reparación de las paredes de la escuela que están en muy malas condiciones.
Pintar toda la escuela.
Comprar materiales de enseñanza para cada materia (ej. microscopios, brújulas, libros, programas informáticos, etc.).
Comprar materiales básicos (ej. lápices, crayones, cuadernos, sacapuntas, pegamento, etc.)

La  fundación
Los fondos se presentaran como parte de la Fundación de Educación Arcelia, una fundación que estoy en el proceso de establecer en honor a mi increible madre que sacrificó mucho para yo pudiera conseguir una buena educación. El objetivo de esta fundación es de ayudar a los niños en situaciones desfavorecidas y socio-económicamente en desventaja para obtener una educación sólida.
El maratón de San Rafael-Huejucar
Este maratón es único ya que nunca se ha corrido la ruta anteriormente. Cuando yo era estudiante de licenciatura , corrí mi primer maratón para recaudar fondos para una fundación local y desde entonces he hecho seis maratones en total. Desde hace años, he soñado con regresar a San Rafael y correr un maratón allí con el propósito de recaudar fondos para los niños de Escuadrón 201. El momento es ahora. 
Teniendo en cuenta que San Rafael está a medio camino entre las localidades de Monte Escobedo y Huejucar, y sorprendentemente, la distancia entre estas dos ciudades es un poco más de un maratón de largo (42.2 km), correré esa ruta. Los  maratones son generalmente difíciles, pero el hecho de que voy a correr a mas de 2,500 metros sobre el nivel del mar, sé que va a ser una tarea muy difícil. Sin embargo, sé que con tu apoyo y con el hecho de que esta es una causa muy importante para mí, se que voy a tener éxito…  aunque acabare muy adolorido!
Otras maneras que puedes ayudar
Tus donaciones son fundamentales, pero también puedes ayudar a correr la voz. Por favor, comparte con tus amigos, familiares, compañeros de trabajo, organizaciones, etc. a través de correo electrónico, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn, etc.
Muchas gracias por tu ayuda. Por favor, dona tan generosamente que te sea posible. Juntos vamos a tener un impacto directo en las vidas y el futuro de estos niños y su comunidad.

story:
Short Summary

The East Bay Solidarity Network is a volunteer organization that helps workers and tenants stand up against abusive bosses, landlords and banks.  A large part of what we do is to organize campaigns against wage theft, deposit theft, and other routine abuses that we face as working people. We also want to help organize our neighborhoods to prevent foreclosures and evictions. We are primarily based in West Oakland, which has been particularly hard-hit by the economic crisis and historically has been a site of displacement, gentrification, but also of fierce grassroots resistance.

Our group is modeled off of the Seattle Solidarity Network (video above). We believe that working people and our communities are capable of solving our problems directly, without the use of expensive, ineffective and time-consuming lawyers and state bureaucracies. This model has proven to be highly effective in other similar organizations around the country, and we are excited to expand our work here in Oakland with the help of your donation!

Every day, people just like us are being robbed of their wages or their deposits, forced to live in shabby apartments and spend half their paychecks (or more) on rent, or pushed out of their own neighborhoods by skyrocketing rents, greedy developers and shady bank practices. Our organization is here to help each other stand up for our dignity and fight back to defend our jobs, our homes, our neighborhoods and our lives. But we need your help!


What We Need & What You Get

We have set a goal of $1,000 to help us grow and strengthen the work of the East Bay Solidarity Network. This money will primarily go into printed materials like posters and flyers. One of the main ways people hear about our organization is through our posters which we put up all over town. Some other ways we use our funds (or have used them in the past):

-Producing original materials, such as a booklet on the history of gentrification, evictions and resistance in West Oakland.

-Throwing BBQ's for the neighborhood, which helps us meet new folks, find out what the problems are that people are facing, build up our membership and our relationships with our neighbors.

-Sending organizers to build ties with people around the country. Last July we sent four organizers from Oakland to the first-ever "International Solidarity Network Convergence" in Seattle, where they got to meet and coordinate with other Solidarity Network organizers from around North America and beyond. 

Whether or not we meet our goal, the funds we raise will be put back directly into the task of growing our organization and reaching out to workers and tenants in our community who are facing abuse and exploitation. As a scrappy, all-volunteer organization, we appreciate every donation we receive!

The Impact

As the gap between the rich and the poor grows ever-wider, we feel it is crucial to develop new and more effective ways at defending our communities from the attacks of the 1%. The Solidarity Network is a concrete way that we can support each other against the abuse and exploitation we face on a day-to-day basis. Through winning tangible gains in our community, we are laying the groundwork for larger struggles aimed at structural change and creating a new and more just world.

As we have seen from the successful track-record of groups in Seattle (over 35 successful campaigns in less than six years!), this model can be an inspiration for a new direction in social movement organizing. The Solidarity Network shows our community that we are capable of fighting back and winning simply by organizing each other, and using creative direct action to get what we want.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to donate at this time, there are still lots of ways for you to help build this organization!

  • Get the word out about our fundraising campaign! Share this page with friends and family and encourage them to donate what they can!
  • Start your own Solidarity Network in your home town! If you are in the Bay and would like to sit down with us to talk about how to do this, that would be great too! Or we can send you a pamphlet that details step-by-step how to get a Solidarity Network started! 
  • Become a member of East Bay Solidarity! All this requires is for you to a.) commit to attending actions when we have them (to the best of your ability), and b.) identify with the mission of our organization. As a member you are also welcome to attend our weekly meetings. And if you are interested in committing more time to the organization, you can join our organizing team! These are the folks that take responsibility for the day-to-day functioning of the group.
  • Know anyone in the East Bay who is having trouble with a boss or landlord? Have them give us a call! 510-239-3219
  • Check out our website, eastbaysol.wordpress.com

story:
The HIP-HOP academy was established in 2006.

Our goal is to properly educate and expose the youth to the elements of HIP-HOP culture that exist as positive forms of self expression.

Emceeing(Rap), Breakdanceing ,Turntableism/ DJ'ing & Graffiti/Mural art each provide a solid artistic foundation for children and young adults.

Pop culture has often painted a negative image of HIP-HOP with its focus on violence and degradation of women, we are here to change that.

Ignorance of HIP-HOP culture stems from lack of exposure and misrepresentation in the media.

All instructors are active artists in HIP-HOP and the Kansas City fine art community with 15+ years of experience.

Jeremy McConnell H.H.A. cofounder, creative visual artist, Community Activist and founder of FLAVORPAK. (B.A.S.C! - Beware All Stylebiters Crew)

Teri (T BLAZE) Green, Poetry & Rhyme Instructor, accomplished Spoken word poet, published author and singer.

Leo (LEONIGHTUS) Gayden, dance instructor, dancer, cultural event coordinator & prolific club dj.

Aaron Sutton H.H.A. cofounder, Visual Arts instructor, artist, community activist, creative collaborater and Emcee (Deep Thinkers, Innate Sounds Crew, Symbol Heavy, Visual Goodies, Soul Mec...)

Michael Brass, Rhyme Instructor, Emcee, Community Activist, Creative Collaborator. ( Heetmob, The Hymnlayas...)

 Roscoe Johnson (Negro Scoe) *On Sabbatical * H.H.A. Cofounder, Rhyme Instructor, Emcee. ( Hip Hop Addicts, Symbol Heavy )

We have a large number of other talented artists from our community that have worked with us over the past few years and that are on call to assist with programming, events and presentations.

Over the past 7 years the Hip Hop Academy has received periodic donations and also been fortunate enough to partner with some area Non for Profit organizations to acquire funding, for the most part however we've run the program on a very small budget that has provided seasonal workshops and occasional block party events.  

The HIP-HOP ACADEMY would benefit from any financial donation and if we are able to reach the desired goal of $8k will be able to provide classes free for the youth around the metropolitan KCMO area.

We continue to believe in EACH ONE TEACH ONE and to be resourceful and creative in our methods and in sharing our Hip Hop art forms with the youth.

Here in Kansas City we have seen many of our neighborhood schools closed, budgets slashed and even accredidation lost. All of these negatively impact our children's future.

Due to a lack of art programs for inner city youth the HIP-HOP ACADEMY has established itself as an independent artist run organization. We have a good track record and have had the opportunity to work with hundreds of youth since 2006 from Pre K to Highschool Graduates.

We truly hope that you can help fund the Hip Hop Academy.

We believe that everyone wants to see children expressing themselves in positive ways.

We will benefit from whatever we raise from this campaign and even if you cannot donate, then please help us get the word out, remember ~ EACH ONE TEACH ONE and that what you do today has a big effect on the future generations.

Thank you for your time and support.

See YOU at the next event and or H.H.A. class.

story:
Who are we?

We are part of the Libanon Lyceum in Rotterdam, Netherlands. The name 'Libanon' is because our school was located in the Libanon street many years ago.

In the Netherlands we have a shortage op people with a technical education. In the last couple of years several initiatives were initiated to get children interested in higher technical education. Our project is one of them but we work closely with other initiatives.

7 years ago we started teaching robotics in our computer classes and found out a lot of children wanted to dig deeper and our first First Lego league team was born.

Today we have 6 FLL teams in competition. 5 of them are integrated in the regular schedule and there is our team, former known as 'Libanon Lego' but now called 'Dutch Delta'.

Team Dutch Delta is coached by volunteers and is currently FLL champion of the Netherlands.

Our main goal still is getting children interested in technical education and during the year our students and coaches give FLL demonstrations and Mindstorms workshops all over the country. All of them non-profit and for free.  

What we need and wherefore:

We want to raise money for 2 things:

First of all we are very proud of the technical skills our students have developed, but there's a financial downside as well. We are invited to participate the First Lego League world festival in St Louis USA, basically the FLL world championship.

As coaches we want our services to be free of charge, so children can participate no matter what the financial situation of the parents is.

Our goal is to travel to the US with 6 students and 2 adult coaches. In total this will cost us 11960 euro.

This budget is built up as follows:

Airline tickets:  6560 euro
Reservation costs: 200 euro
Hotel: 3160 euro
Food and beverages: 1440 euro
Local transport: 600 euro

Total: 11960 euro

Second, there are the free workshops we offer.

In 2014 we will at least give one big workshop / FLL demonstration during Legoworld (70.000 spectators).
In 2013 this 7 day event cost us 1750 euro.

Buying and replacing material (mindstorms kits) will cost us aprox 800 euro on a yearly base.

We have 3000 euro in cash and want to raise 10000 euro in total.

The Impact

Donating will give us a chance to give this First Lego League team the experience of participating the FLL World festival. For several years these students are giving up loads of free time only to give other children the chance of programming and learning robotics. It will be a well-deserved and educational trip.

But more importantly, it will give us coaches and our students the chance to continue our quest of showing children how interesting the world of technics can be :)

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

What you can do is join us in our quest. Find a local FLL team to support, there are never enough coaches, or help starting up a new team on a not yet participating high school.

story:
Please continue to share our campaign! Our families are planning to travel to Germany and the costs of passports and travel were not factored into our original campaign goal total... the campaign closes soon... we need your help.  Thank you.  

We are now helping two families

Mohammed has asked us to host Samir and his family as well as his own. So, we are committed to helping a second refugee family - so each will now each have cultural and social support in a village with no other Syrian nationals. The families we are supporting are two married couples, each with a two year old child (one girl, one boy) and both mum's are pregnant with due dates in May.

There is no limit on the amount that can be raised. We need your help to support these families who will be staying with us at least until May... and depending on birth dates, may be until August.

We have taken on much more than we originally planned and for at the start of this campaign so: 

Please keep sharing and contributing!

For regular news, please click the "Updates" tag at the top of this page.

Short Summary

My name is Judith and I'm a UK national living in Bulgaria with my Irish partner Declan. When we heard of the difficulties in the Syrian Refugee camps in Sofia, we wanted to help.  We have a second house in our village that is currently not in use. So, on the 17th December 2013 Declan and I drove to Sofia to the Vrajdebna Refugee camp to meet with our Syrian contact Radi, who has lived in Bulgaria for several years and is working to help Syrians in the camps. 

At the camp we were introduced to a young family. On that same day Mohammed, his wife and unborn child (due to be born in April 2014) and their two year old daughter came to stay with us. They are currently back in Sofia awaiting final papers.

Once their paperwork is completed, Mohammed and his family have just 5 days to leave the refugee camp. They will be given 65 leva (33 euros/US$44) when they leave, but will get no other financial assistance.

We are committed to provide for Mohammed and his growing family, but our own budget is tight. We will continue to provide the house rent free and all food from our garden will be shared with them. We are currently looking for work for Mohammed. In the meantime, we would be very grateful for contributions to help to provide nappies and baby formula; clothes for the children; sanitary products; transport costs; household costs.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We will provide Mohammed and his family with accommodation rent free for as long as he and his family need it.
  • All pregnancy care will be taken care of.
  • We will provide food from our garden.
  • We will provide clothes for the adults..
  • We will cover costs in searching for work for Mohammed

If funds allow, we hope to help two families at the same time, which will provide each family with cultural and social support.

We would like help with the following:

  • Wood to heat the house - maximum cost 60 euros per month (that's in winter)
  • Internet access to keep contact with family - 13 euros per month
  • Electricity costs - 15 euros per month
  • Nappies, baby formula and sanitary products - 100+ euros per month
  • Clothes for the baby and child.  A babygro costs 5 euros here.
  • Transport costs - It costs 17 euros for one person to travel to Sofia
  • It is likely that Mohammed will have to travel to town for work - 2 euros return daily.
  • Transport costs to Veliko Tarnovo to meet with the Syrian community - 6 euros for a return trip.
  • Food that cannot be provided from our garden e.g., oil, rice, pasta etc. - 100+ euros per month
We will keep you updated as to how the contributions are being spent. 

When Mohammed and his family leave us, our house will be open to other families should we have the funds to do so.  

Declan and I will not receive any of the donations as 100% of the net proceeds will go to the Syrian families that need it most.  We set a modest goal for this campaign to ensure we achieve the maximum net proceeds to the recipients.  

There is no limit on the amount that can be raised so please contribute as much as you can!! 

The photo on this page is taken from english.al-akhbar.com.  

The video clip is from the UNHCR http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f9iPZSevHdQ  we are not connected to, nor do we endorse [or oppose] the UNHCR.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people can’t contribute, but that does not mean you can’t help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about our aim to help Syrian Refugees in Bulgaria. Facebook and Twitter tools are at the top of this page

If you should have any questions or requests, please do not hesitate to contact me on 07594572439 or judithpride@hotmail.com

Thank you.

For background information on the Syrian conflict visit http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-17258397

We will keep you updated as to how the contributions are being spent. When Mohammed and his family leave us, our house will be open to other families should we have the funds to do so.  Declan and I will not receive any of the donations as 100% of the net proceeds will go to the Syrian families that need it most.  We set a modest goal for this campaign to ensure we achieve the maximum net proceeds to the recipients.  There is no limit on the amount that can be raised so please contribute as much as you can!! The photo on this page is taken from english.al-akhbar.com.  The video clip is from the UNHCR http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f9iPZSevHdQ  we are not connected to, nor do we endorse [or oppose] the UNHCR.Other Ways You Can HelpWe understand that some people can’t contribute, but that does not mean you can’t help:Please get the word out and make some noise about our aim to help Syrian Refugees in Bulgaria. Facebook and Twitter tools are at the top of this page
If you should have any questions or requests, please do not hesitate to contact me on 07594572439 or judithpride@hotmail.comThank you.For background information on the Syrian conflict visit http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-17258397

story:
THANKS FOR HELPING US REACH OUR FUNDING GOAL IN JUST 5 DAYS!


We are so grateful for our community of supporters.  We are leaving the site up for a few more days in case others would like to contribute.  Above the $1,000 goal, here is what your money will pay for:

  • Printing longer, better, higher quality catalogs
  • Printing more catalogs and doing more publicity
  • Helping workers purchase necessities for their centers

We are so grateful for your support.  What we need now is an audience, so please like www.facebook.com/PicturingChange and follow us!

Short Summary

India has the largest free childcare system in the world.  The childcare centers, called anganwadis, are run by local women called anganwadi workers.  They are more than just childcare providers: they are political advocates who fight for the rights of the women and children in their communities.  Yet, they are  largely invisible. 

In this project, Mathangi Subramanian (a former teacher and a Fulbright scholar) and Greeshma Patel (a professional photographer) are partnering to put cameras in the hands of anganwadi workers to document their stories.  

We will train the workers to use digital cameras during a six week workshop.  At the end, we will feature the photostories they produce in multiple venues, including a local art gallery (Thalam), an NGO-run blog, and our Facebook Page. We'll also share these photos with the Ministry of Women and Child Development to expose policymakers to what the workers believe needs to change.  

What We Need & What You Get

Your contribution helps pay for:

  • Six digital cameras that the workers will keep.
  • Installation costs in a gallery including printing, framing, and supplies.
  • Food and rental costs of the gallery, where we will hold the workshops.

If we don't reach our goal, we will use whatever we earn to buy cameras.

In return, you're eligible to receive original artwork that comes out of the workshops, credit in the catalogue, and thank you postcards from the workers.  Plus, you'll get some great karma!

The Impact

Here's why this project is so important to us: 

First and foremost, we love these women.  They have incredible stories.  The world needs to hear them.

Policymakers need to know more about these women.  We have a good relationship with local government officials, so we're going to invite them to the events and share the photos with them. 

The general public should know more about what anganwadis do.  That way they can help build political will to improve the conditions of women and children throughout India.

These women deserve the chance to express themselves publicly.  They give everything they have to their communities.  It's time they did something for themselves.

Here's why the two of us are the best people for the project:

Mathangi has a decade of experience teaching and training, and she's run digital storytelling workshops with everyone from teachers to formerly incarcerated youth to private school going third graders. She's spent the past seven month researching anganwadis in India.  

Greeshma is a graduate of the National Institute of Fashion Technology who left the fashion industry to pursue photography.  She now specializes in photographing children and families.  Check out her work on her web site, www,greeshma.com.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • If you have digital cameras you can donate, contact us.
  • Spread the word about the campaign using the Indiegogo share tools.
  • When the exhibition / blog happens, tell your friend about it.
  • Connect us with online and print publications that might display the work.
  • Come to our opening event and support Thalam and other nonprofit galleries.
  • Find out about the childcare system in your country, and support childcare workers all over the world!

story:
Hi, I'm Maddie.

I am a sophomore and in Advanced Art. And, luckily, that qualifies me for the Italy trip!  The mere thought of Italy completely fascinates me--and I would get to see some incredibly beautiful art and experience the culture.  

If I got the privilege to go to Italy, I would be forever grateful.  During our stay there, we will explore Venice with a guide; see churches, baptistries, and art in Florence; explore San Gimignano; travel a high speed train from to Naples and continue on to Sorrento; visit and take a tour Pompeii and the island of Capri; drive to Rome and visit forums, arches, and the colosseum; and visit the Vatican museum, Sistine Chapel, and St. Peter's Basilica.  All of these sound like amazing activities that I would absolutely love to experience.  

I will need $4,500 for this trip.  That money will be spent paying for airfare, hotels, tours, and food.  

Perks for donations include:

$25 - Set of 4 Greeting Cards of My Artwork, Blank Inside

$50 - Handmade Sugar Skull Light Switch Plate by Slightly Smitten Kitten & Set of 4 Greeting Cards 

$75 - Limited Edition Print of my Artwork

$100 - Limited Edition Print + Greeting Cards

$250 - Original Pop Art Painting done by Maddie Teece

$1000+ - Original Triptych by Me


If I do not reach my funding goal, I am hoping to still be able to go on this trip.  If I am not able to attend this trip, the money raised will go towards my college education.

This trip is valuable to me because it can help extend my knowledge of other countries and cultures, famous art pieces, and of Italian History.  

If unable to make a money contribution, I am still grateful for the time you took to read this.  It would be quite splendid if word could be put out about my campaign, whether it be word of mouth or a link posted to Facebook.  There is a share tool on this page! 

Thank you all so much,

Maddie

story:
I'm René Barnett, a tv/filmmaker, radio host and researcher in Los Angeles. More than 30 years ago, I read a book that dramatically changed my life and shook the entire world with its controversial theses about early Christianity, Jesus, Mary Magdalene and the implications of these hot button ideas. The book, Holy Blood, Holy Grail, and all subsequent books, articles and films on the subject matter have come as a result of one man's discoveries and keen eye for coded messages.  That man is Henry Lincoln.

 Now, Mr. Lincoln’s extensive archives will be made available to all those who are interested to see them. In addition, we desire to document on film the "re-discoveries" by Henry as he goes through 'treasure' boxes that haven't been opened in decades and his thoughts and recollections as the archive team goes through each document, each photograph, each manuscript, each letter and each note in order to organize and share with researchers now and to come.

 In 1982 the publication of HBHG was to have a profound effect upon modern attitudes and thinking. The International Herald Tribune said: “To call Holy Blood, Holy Grail controversial would be an understatement … The book’s contentions have met a religious fire storm.“ Hundreds of books have since been written, attempting to demolish – or to support – the hypothesis put forward in its pages. 

What had begun ten years earlier in a BBC documentary film’s attempt to unravel a little local mystery in the foothills of the French Pyrenees has now spawned an industry. Films have been made, novels written and fantasies concocted in its wake. But genuine, provable and astonishing discoveries have been made. Discoveries which shed an unexpected and startling new light upon the history of our Western Civilisation.

From its inception, one man has been intimately involved in the extraordinary research which has led to changes in the world’s thinking about Christianity, the role of women and … even more importantly … the realization that we have much still to learn about the beliefs, the knowledge and the skills of our remote ancestors.

Now in his ninth decade, the necessity to preserve Henry Lincoln’s archive has become a priority. 

Documents, photographs, recordings, books, films, diagrams, scripts, maps and manuscripts demonstrate the growth of the hypotheses and the many detours and stumbling blocks, which have led to new ideas and new attitudes. Future scholars will find that the contents of this archive can help in the understanding of many of the changes in society, which came in the second half of the twentieth century. 

Whether Henry Lincoln’s arguments are accepted … or not … their effect has been undeniable.

 This is what Lincoln had to say about the archive project:

 Why does this archive matter to me ?    More importantly – why does it matter at all?   

I did not set out to produce this body of work.   I was not trying to find a subject which would give me a ‘best-seller’.   I was simply an actor/cum writer who stumbled upon an exciting yarn, which might have the makings of a brief television programme.   It was simply “part of the job” … just one more script to help with paying the bills.   When I began to research the story, I thought that the subject would be written, filmed, seen and forgotten within the year.  But Rennes-le-Château was bigger than that … bigger than I had imagined … and bigger than most people yet realise.
Throughout the years of struggling to understand, of confronting the distortions of “History” as it was being taught, of being shocked by the discoveries which I was making, I was constantly amazed by the hostility which I encountered among those in the academic world.   I was an ‘outsider’ and so had no place in their self-satisfied society.  The ‘biblical’ distortions of the theological community were easier to comprehend and to accept.   After all, here I was confronting ‘Faith’.   And it is not easy to question long-held beliefs.  But what I found truly shocking was the dishonesty which I encountered in the media.   ...  But when a supposedly respectable journal began to peddle patent untruths, I realised that Rennes-le-Château was touching nerves in an establishment of which I had no desire to be part.

And so, for the last thirty years, I have been content to plough my own furrow and to ignore the opinions of those who – at the most generous – were speaking from a position of wilfully blinkered and self-imposed ignorance.

So – why should my archive matter ?     It matters because it will demonstrate a Truth.   Not simply the truth of what I have discovered – but also, I hope, the honesty which I have tried to bring to the work.   

I am humbled by what I have learned of our forebears’ genius.  And this I wish to share.  It is for others with the requisite skills and expertise to go where I lack the knowledge to follow.  My archive will save them time.   

 There is no need to find again what I have already found.   As I wrote in The Holy Place :“I have entered a ‘treasure chamber’ … But I suspect that I have glimpsed only a small part of the treasure.”

Sapiens nihil affirmat quod non probet.   The wise man affirms nothing, which he cannot prove … and the beginnings of the proofs lie within the archive.
As I enter my eighty-fourth year I am content to stand on the shore and wish Bon Voyage to whoever may wish to undertake the journey upon which I have made the first faltering steps.

 As a researcher and huge Henry Lincoln fan, I'm more than honored to be a part of this project to organize, protect and preserve the extensive archives of author and documentarian Henry Lincoln whose work has had such a profound sociological impact. The end goal is to provide to all researchers Henry's many documents, letters, photographs, artefacts, videos and notes from a half century of research. The intention is that this huge body of research into the very complex and compelling subjects surrounding the mysterious French village of Rennes-le-Chateau and what is now commonly referred to as the Da Vinci Code mysteries shall be housed in a small self-sustaining museum and learning center in the relevant Languedoc Region of southwest France.

 We are currently seeking seed funding in the amount of $7,725 to assist in the initiation of the project by covering immediate project expenses, including, but not limited to materials, air fares, accommodations, communications and filming costs. 

Anyone contributing $25 or more will be specially recognized as a supporter of the project and be privy to inside information about the project as it goes forward.

We are also compiling a list of individuals who wish to participate by volunteering time and skills, so please share this campaign as widely as you like. Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thanks so much for your interest and support for this very important project which will carry on far into the future!  - René Barnett

story:
Hi,

I am Fernanda Ramirez, a seventeen year old international student in Canada from Mexico who is passionate about dancing, designing and helping others. I am a girl that believes in a better world! 

I believe that changing the world is hard, but not impossible. I am a “citizen of the world”, no matter how proud or how much I love my own country, helping others around the world is a magical inspiration that keeps me going. Since the age of eight I am an active contributor to different social causes, participating in several bake sales, bazars, education programs, etc. I am a girl that always wants to go further and do great things. At the age of 15, I decided to move abroad into Canada by myself with the goal of having a new perspective of the world. The same year, I joined different groups and organizations, waning to make a difference. As part of my participation in the Global Issues Club, I support and fundraise for numerous campaigns by Free The Children. In addition, I have participated in Model United Nations for several times debating and trying to find a possible solution for Child Labour problems, Women rights, and other actual world problems. I believe that our generation is not only the future but the present capable of anything.

                                   Vancouver Model United Nations 2012 (I am the one in yellow)


After being involved in different local, national and international campaigns and realizing how many wonderful and plenty opportunities one can take to make a difference. This year, I got invited to be part of WE DAY, inspirational event that filled my body with excitement. I listened to the numerous and recognized figures that share with everyone their passion and ideas for a better world. My heart pumped like never before and made me decide to go even father while sharing it to the world to make awareness. The idea of not only supporting or helping from the facilities of home and school, but the actual act of going to a new far away country and building schools myself next to other volunteers seems not only an incredible experience but also a unique way to make an impact. 

                                                                                           WE DAY 2012 in Vancouver 


Because of my love not only to help but to share and learn from others, I am taking the challenge and adventure of going to India this summer with Free The Children for promoting education while building schools and allowing young children to have dreams, hope and a better future. “Education is power". I strongly believe that education is the key to a better world; therefore, I want this trip not only to be a simple summer act but a strong and permanent legacy. In addition, I want this trip to be a whole movement of awareness, change, and strong impact towards a greater world. The service in my veins encourages me to help daily and to go huge and beyond.


                      

                                                             Photo from ME TO WE TRIP add video.  

                                   http://www.metowe.com/volunteer-travel/youth-trips/india


Going to India is completely my idea and even though my parents love me, they will not give me any money for the trip and I need to earn it my self. The trip is $4,995. However, this price does not includes the plane tickets all the way from Mexico and neither does it includes the vacuums, visa papers, etc. All the extra expenses is almost the same as the trip and I need everyone's help to make this dream and good cause possible.Therefore, I am hoping to fundraise $8000 for me to be capable of fully pay all the needs for the trip. I am aware is a lot of money, but I am sure that with your help I will make it. The $8000 will include:

Plance tickets from Mexico-India and back
Accommodations
Three meals daily
Bottled and/or purified water
All the needed Vacuums 
Visa papers fees
Entrance fees to the group activities (as part of the Me to We program)
Language lessons (as part of the Me to We program)
Volunteer placement activities 
Leaderships training (including comprehensive action planning) 
24-hour emergency service. 


There is a numerous amount of valuable perks that you would be able to enjoy after donating. I will try to do my best for all the perks to sound and be great! Some of the perks will include my personal designs, sketches, etc during and after India!


                                                                                            By: Fernanda Ramirez

                           One of my Original and Unique Designs spired by the Hindu culture


                          

                   "What if the cure for cancer is trapped inside the mind of                        
                                  someone who can't afford education"


Everyone can contribute for a better world, and little by little I am sure we can make a change. My plan is to not only go to this wonderful trip but to gain new knowledge and later use it for a positive impact. I will start blogging, face-booking, and twitting, to show all my thoughts and experience starting through my fundraising until the end of the trip. I want to show the impact and outcome as well as my plans to use the tools gained after India. I want everyone to be part of the journey as well as to be aware of the situations that one might not be familiar with in a daily environment and could greatly affect the world or oneself.  I want my trip to be a life changing expirience not only to me and to the Hindu people but to everyone that supports me. I would like this trip and adventure to be an example for others to take action and start helping.


                                                           Screen shot of my Twitter:  @FERAMIREZ_NET


                & FACEBOOK:

  Screen shot of my Facebook:    
 https://www.facebook.com/pages/Fernanda-Ramirez/685861561441003


In addition, to make my campaign strong and engaging, I started busking and performing Flamenco around the streets and in social events last month. The idea of combing two of my strongest passions blow my mind and now I am planning to dance everywhere as possible to share my love for life and for service. 


                                                              Busking in the streets of Cowichan Valley 

                                                                                                   (December 2013) 


All my performances will be taped or pictured for everyone to enjoy in my updates or in my WIX BLOG ( http://mramir30.wix.com/changing-the-world ) that will be available to see starting from February 16 2014. Everyone will be capable of not only follow my experience but also to be part of it. I will be posting everyday something about my campaign through my social media like: news, plans, objectives, events, or even some inspiring thoughts/quotes part of my journey.   


BUT WAIT! That is not it... I will be also Sharing extra little ways of helping one's community and the world. I will be doing random acts of kindness that will not only promote my campaign but will change the lives of othersCheck out my journey and all the small or big acts that will take part of my campaign. 


DON'T FORGET TO DONATE, SHARE IT, LIKE IT, FOLLOW, TWEET ABOUT IT, SCREAM ABOUT IT OR WHAT EVER YOU WOULD THINK IS A GOOD IDEA TO SUPPORT THE CAMPAIGN! :D ...AND NEVER EVER STOP HELPING OTHERS, NEVER STOP HELPING THE WORLD!
story_txt:
Hi,

I am Fernanda Ramirez, a seventeen year old international student in Canada from Mexico who is passionate about dancing, designing and helping others. I am a girl that believes in a better world! I believe that changing the world is hard, but not impossible. I am a “citizen of the world”, no matter how proud or how much I love my own country, helping others around the world is a magical inspiration that keeps me going. Since the age of eight I am an active contributor to different social causes, participating in several bake sales, bazars, education programs, etc. I am a girl that always wants to go further and do great things. At the age of 15, I decided to move abroad into Canada by myself with the goal of having a new perspective of the world. The same year, I joined different groups and organizations, waning to make a difference. As part of my participation in the Global Issues Club, I support and fundraise for numerous campaigns by Free The Children. In addition, I have participated in Model United Nations for several times debating and trying to find a possible solution for Child Labour problems, Women rights, and other actual world problems. I believe that our generation is not only the future but the present capable of anything.
                                   Vancouver Model United Nations 2012 (I am the one in yellow)After being involved in different local, national and international campaigns and realizing how many wonderful and plenty opportunities one can take to make a difference. This year, I got invited to be part of WE DAY, inspirational event that filled my body with excitement. I listened to the numerous and recognized figures that share with everyone their passion and ideas for a better world. My heart pumped like never before and made me decide to go even father while sharing it to the world to make awareness. The idea of not only supporting or helping from the facilities of home and school, but the actual act of going to a new far away country and building schools myself next to other volunteers seems not only an incredible experience but also a unique way to make an impact.                                                                                            WE DAY 2012 in Vancouver Because of my love not only to help but to share and learn from others, I am taking the challenge and adventure of going to India this summer with Free The Children for promoting education while building schools and allowing young children to have dreams, hope and a better future. “Education is power". I strongly believe that education is the key to a better world; therefore, I want this trip not only to be a simple summer act but a strong and permanent legacy. In addition, I want this trip to be a whole movement of awareness, change, and strong impact towards a greater world. The service in my veins encourages me to help daily and to go huge and beyond.                                                                                   Photo from ME TO WE TRIP add video.                                     http://www.metowe.com/volunteer-travel/youth-trips/indiaGoing to India is completely my idea and even though my parents love me, they will not give me any money for the trip and I need to earn it my self. The trip is $4,995. However, this price does not includes the plane tickets all the way from Mexico and neither does it includes the vacuums, visa papers, etc. All the extra expenses is almost the same as the trip and I need everyone's help to make this dream and good cause possible.Therefore, I am hoping to fundraise $8000 for me to be capable of fully pay all the needs for the trip. I am aware is a lot of money, but I am sure that with your help I will make it. The $8000 will include:Plance tickets from Mexico-India and backAccommodationsThree meals dailyBottled and/or purified waterAll the needed Vacuums Visa papers feesEntrance fees to the group activities (as part of the Me to We program)Language lessons (as part of the Me to We program)Volunteer placement activities Leaderships training (including comprehensive action planning) 24-hour emergency service. There is a numerous amount of valuable perks that you would be able to enjoy after donating. I will try to do my best for all the perks to sound and be great! Some of the perks will include my personal designs, sketches, etc during and after India!                                                                                            By: Fernanda Ramirez                           One of my Original and Unique Designs spired by the Hindu culture                                             "What if the cure for cancer is trapped inside the mind of                                                           someone who can't afford education"Everyone can contribute for a better world, and little by little I am sure we can make a change. My plan is to not only go to this wonderful trip but to gain new knowledge and later use it for a positive impact. I will start blogging, face-booking, and twitting, to show all my thoughts and experience starting through my fundraising until the end of the trip. I want to show the impact and outcome as well as my plans to use the tools gained after India. I want everyone to be part of the journey as well as to be aware of the situations that one might not be familiar with in a daily environment and could greatly affect the world or oneself.  I want my trip to be a life changing expirience not only to me and to the Hindu people but to everyone that supports me. I would like this trip and adventure to be an example for others to take action and start helping.                                                           Screen shot of my Twitter:  @FERAMIREZ_NET                & FACEBOOK:  Screen shot of my Facebook:      https://www.facebook.com/pages/Fernanda-Ramirez/685861561441003In addition, to make my campaign strong and engaging, I started busking and performing Flamenco around the streets and in social events last month. The idea of combing two of my strongest passions blow my mind and now I am planning to dance everywhere as possible to share my love for life and for service.                                                               Busking in the streets of Cowichan Valley                                                                                                    (December 2013) All my performances will be taped or pictured for everyone to enjoy in my updates or in my WIX BLOG ( http://mramir30.wix.com/changing-the-world ) that will be available to see starting from February 16 2014. Everyone will be capable of not only follow my experience but also to be part of it. I will be posting everyday something about my campaign through my social media like: news, plans, objectives, events, or even some inspiring thoughts/quotes part of my journey.   BUT WAIT! That is not it... I will be also Sharing extra little ways of helping one's community and the world. I will be doing random acts of kindness that will not only promote my campaign but will change the lives of othersCheck out my journey and all the small or big acts that will take part of my campaign. DON'T FORGET TO DONATE, SHARE IT, LIKE IT, FOLLOW, TWEET ABOUT IT, SCREAM ABOUT IT OR WHAT EVER YOU WOULD THINK IS A GOOD IDEA TO SUPPORT THE CAMPAIGN! :D ...AND NEVER EVER STOP HELPING OTHERS, NEVER STOP HELPING THE WORLD!

story:
The Nicole Sangsuree Barrett Scholarship Fund

Nicole Sangsuree Barrett was an extraordinary young woman who left a legacy of love, creativity, beauty, and activism. We have established this scholarship fund to honor her spirit and support other activists to have the opportunity to participate in the Buddhist Education for Social Transformation (BEST) training program in northern Thailand. Sangsuree graduated from the first cohort of BEST in 2014 and was on the faculty for the second year of the program at the time of her death.

Our goal is to fund three BEST scholarships through this campaign, in Sangsuree's memory.


Who Was Nicole Sangsuree Barrett?

As a songwriter, artist, musician, puppeteer, farmer, and teacher, Sangsuree gave herself completely to the cause of liberation and justice for all beings. She fully embraced her own identity as a mixed-race, queer woman. 

Sangsuree earned her bachelor’s in theater arts and women and gender studies from the University of Oregon, and completed a graduate degree at Portland State University just this past year. She taught an urban farming series at Portland Community College and worked as a waste reduction educator. In Thailand, Sangsuree studied seed saving and natural building at Pun Pun Organic Farm, and she became deeply involved with the work of the International Women's Partnership for Peace and Justice, based north of Chiang Mai. You can read more about her many accomplishments in this article by Heather Spalding, director of the PSU Sustainability Leadership Center, who worked with Sangsuree. 

Sang's love of the earth was palpable and some of the greatest gifts she gave to all of us were rituals and songs that helped us to re-connect with the wisdom inherent in nature. One of the last songs Sang recorded, with the help of Emma Carroll, was "Fistful of Bones," her original song woven around a beautiful chant, "Earth My Body."


Beyond all this description, Sang was simply unforgettable -- someone who had the rare gift of shining herself while at the same time creating space for others to come forth and shine. As one friend put it, 

"She spied your highest potential, your unseen sides, and knew exactly how you need to be encouraged, 'C'mon now, I see You in there, show me. You don't gotta hide.' Sang was an activist, but her most potent social change work was surely made through her every day interactions, insatiable curiosity for people, loving kindness and whacky humour. Plus uncanny inability not to begin accidental-jam-session-talent-sharing-celebrations that go all night."

Sang was only 34 years old when she was killed after being hit by a car in Chiang Mai on the night of July 17. As news of her death spread, the many communities she was part of have come forward to express their great love and respect for her, and to connect with each other. This, too, is part of Sang's legacy -- a growing awareness of our points of connection and an aspiration to support the work of healing and liberation going on in many quarters. 


    What is the Buddhist Education for Social Transformation Training Program?

      "Through the BEST program, I am exploring engaged spiritual practice and deep ecology. I am committed to walk the path of sustainable living in China, no matter how lonely it may seem to be, because I feel so much support from the peaceful, joyful spirits here at IWP, expressing so much lovingkindness (especially Sangsuree)."

      ~Fang, BEST 2014 participant from China

      The Buddhist Education for Social Transformation (BEST) course is an innovative yearlong training that is focused on transformation of individuals, communities, the environment, and the world. 

      The program is open to anyone seeking a Buddhist perspective in his or her approach to personal development, social justice and social change work. The program is organized by International Women’s Partnership for Peace and Justice (IWP), based in Chiang Mai, Thailand and builds on IWP's experience working with social change agents from the grassroots to the government levels over the past 15 years. IWP was co-founded by Ouyporn Khuankaew and Ginger Norwood in 2002.

      Course participants come from all over Asia as well as other parts of the world. Graduates and current students are from Australia, China,  Colombia, India, Myanmar, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand, and the U.S.

      The course is founded on the pillars of non-violent activism, spiritual practice, and anti-oppression feminism. The course is intended to support participants’ integration of spiritual practice and social action, grounded in structural analysis and an understanding of the interdependence of personal transformation and structural change. The intention is to form a strong community/sangha among participants as they journey through the yearlong program together.

      Nicole Sangsuree was part of the first BEST course in 2013 and graduated from the training in June 2014. She had stayed on at IWP in July of 2014 and was teaching yoga to the new BEST cohort and supporting them in many other ways at the time of her death.

      Your contribution to this fund will help to provide full-tuition scholarships for three people to participate in the 2015 BEST course. Tuition for each student is $800 for the full year of training, all-inclusive (housing, food, course fee, mentoring)... $800 x 3 = $2400. Any funds raised beyond this goal will go to offer more scholarships to applicants in need of financial assistance to enroll in BEST. There are generally between 12 to 20 people in each BEST cohort, many of whom are working in NGOs and coming from low-income communities.


      "During my stay in Thailand last summer, I attended a training program called Buddhist Education for Social Transformation (BEST), where I had the privilege of meeting and becoming friends with several extraordinary women from all over the world. Sangsuree was one of those women. She was many things - activist, singer, poet, writer - the list goes on. Most importantly, she was generous, creative, beautiful, funny, light-hearted, passionate, accepting and one of the most kind-hearted individuals I have ever met. While her physical body has left us, her spirit lives on and her light continues to shine brightly in our hearts. I feel honoured to have known her."

      ~Marissa Rykiss


      Photo: Sangsuree (left) and the graduates of the first BEST training, June 2014


        Other Ways You Can Help

        If you're not able to contribute to the scholarship fund at this time, you can still help out by sharing the word about this campaign with others via:

        • Facebook, Twitter, other social media -- use the sharing buttons at the top of this page
        • Word-of-Mouth... write about it, tell others!

story:
The Campaign

The Code Green campaign was born in March of 2014 in response to the high number of suicides in first responders such as EMTs, Paramedics, Firefighters, Dispatchers and Police Officers. The reality is that mental health issues like depression, anxiety, substance abuse, PTSD and suicide are significantly higher in these groups than they are in the general public but it isn't talked about. 

Unfortunately responders who need help are often left feeling stigmatized and alone and they are not aware of the resources available to help them. We aim to change that by helping reduce the stigma, providing education, and giving responders an outlet to share their stories in their own words. 

Why is Code Green important?

  • Evidence suggests that first responders have PTSD rates equivalent to that of the military. 
  • Over 60 EMTs, Firefighters and Paramedics killed themselves last year, a number that we know was underreported. 
  • Code Green shows first responders that they are not alone in their problems, which reduces the silence and stigma.
  • Code Green will provide education to first responders so they can recognize if they or a coworker needs help.  

What do YOU get out of this fundraiser? 

  • You get awesome Code Green gear! 
  • You get to help Code Green get off the ground and become sustainable. 
  • You get to help spread awareness about mental health issues in first responders. 
  • Did we mention the awesome Code Green gear? (Especially the t-shirt!)

 

What do WE get out of this fundraiser? 

  • We get startup money to get Code Green off the ground. 
  • Around $1000 will go towards getting our Federal 501(c)(3) status as a nonprofit. Getting our 501(c)(3) is critical to growing and being successful. 
  • The rest of the money will go towards operating expenses like accounting software, business cards and other boring business-y stuff. 
  • We get to spread awareness about Code Green and the reason we exist. 

FAQ about the gear.

  • The t-shirt proof will be posted ASAP. The shirts will be unisex and come in adult sizes. They will probably be a light gray. 
  • ALL FOLKS WHO WILL RECEIVE T-SHIRTS need to email us at thecodegreencampaign@gmail.com - that missing 'n' is very important and we don't want you to miss out on your goodies!
  • We can NOT ship outside of the US and Canada.
  • The dog tags and metal bracelets are made in the USA by a small business. 
  • Silicone bracelets are 7.5 inches in diameter.   
  • Metal bracelets are 7.5 inches in diameter and come flat. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate right now? Don't worry, you can still help!

  • Share the link to this fundraiser with your friends and family. 
  • Approach your department about supporting Code Green. 
  • Read, comment on and share the stories found on our website.

story:
This summer marks Pinson Public Library's 5th Summer Reading Program. We have grown so much in a short amount of time and we need your help to continue to grow! 

In 2012, during our first year of SRP, we offered 14 programs for teens and children. In 2013 we offered 40 programs for teens, children and adults. Last year we offered a program a day and want to do the same this summer!!!

We will offer activities for children, events for teens, programs for adults and more! This includes programs about music/art/science, craft events, animal visits and family night programs.

Here are our statistics from last summer:

  • 2,300 people attended 60 programs at the library
  • Over 750 kids, teens and adults registered for the program
  • More than 10,000 books were read!

Just a few reasons it is important to have an engaging Summer Reading Program: 

  • offers encouragement that reading become a lifelong habit
  • reading over the summer helps children prevent the "summer slide"
  • programs provide an opportunity for family time

Please consider making a donation:

Your donation, no matter what the amount ($5, $20, $50, $200) will help us offer more programs! We can stretch your dollars to provide quality programming and entertainment for you and your entire family.

We understand that everyone can't contribute, but please share this with your friends, family and local businesses! Every contribution will help us reach our goal!

Help us reach our goal of "A Program a Day!" for our 2016 Summer Reading Program!
